I also felt, you know, th at Poles were Œ were trying, you know, somehow, you know, to show our superior Œ their Œ their superior powers, or their superior might against a smaller country, and didn™t like it. Didn™t like it at all. Although I was skeptical at that time about Vilnius, you know. I thought well, you know, we are no-not going to recover Vilnius ever. I didn™t tell anybody not Œ not that my father, nor Œ nor my mother, nor Œ nor my friends. But I thought wow, that™s Œ that™s an unrealistic, we might as well fo rget about it. But Œ but this was then a Polish ultimatum, the Polish demand, you know. It still hurt. Still hurt very much, you know. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 48

segments.question: I want to also kind of make a remark is, as I™m listening to you, you™re saying that these events, which are political Œ
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Œ who Œ whose world consists of, I go to work in the morning, I do my job, I come home, I have no interest in Œ in politics, or in what goes around me. I can™t affect it anyway, and what happens in Washington, what happens in Moscow , is none of my affair, okay? And clearly that was not the dynamic going on in the cir Œ in the Œ in the circle of people that you grew up with. Is that so?
segments.answer: That™s true. That™s true, I Œ I Œ I s Œ I Œ I am sure that there were such people, such people are disinterested in Œ in Œ in politics, interethnic relationships, and so I Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 49am sure there were so, but that was not in our Œ in Œ in our circle, in our family, in the friends m-my family had.

segments.question: And why would you Œ ho w would you explain their engagement then? How would you explain their engagement to events that really are outside and beyond their personal lives? By that Œ still at that point, I mean at some point history doesn™t im-impact, but how would yo u explain this interest?
segments.answer: In Œ in such a Œ well, as I mentioned before, you know, the Œ the family history, the people Œ the Œ my father™s experience i-in Œ in Œ in Œ in the War of Independence, and before that he was in Poland during the World War I, you know, an-and the relationship even during that tsarist times, even in their gymnasium, there was already hostility between the Lithuanians and Poles in their classes, he told me. So that Œ

segments.question: I™m asking not so much about that particular relationship, but in Œ in a Œ I guess more direct way would say, why should your parents care what goes on between Kaunas and Warsaw, or Kaunas and Moscow , or Kaunas and Berlin? It™s ha Œ you know, what made your fa mily engaged in caring abou t these political events, in general. Why would you Œ how would you explain it?
segments.answer: I Œ I don™t know, I don™t know. But I know that even my grandfather from my mother™s side, even he was very committed to the Lithuanian national Œ

segments.question: Idea. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 50
segments.answer: Œ and ethnic ideal, right. He was worki ng he Œ with them, he Œ he Œ he was helping during the 1905, 1905 there was a revolution in Russia, and in Lithuania it took a national character; Lithuanians against the Russian suppression. So, why Œ my father hid, you know, the Œ the revolutionaries Œ my grandfather.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: My mother found out, I mean, that he hid the revolutionaries who were trying to get Œ when Œ when the revolution wa s suppressed, trying to get into Germany and later maybe to United States to escape from that pole Œ tsarist oppression. So, you know, it™s tradition going way b ack. And I don™t know how to explain. It was a small country, and the fe Œ people felt that, you know, these things really affect them. The country™s independence was precarious duri ng that time, and of course, I mean, my father was working for the government, so i-if Œ if Œ if the country is occupied, I mean, he has no job. I think maybe that al so had something to do. I Œ really, we didn™t pose those questions that way, so I am not sure.

segments.question: Okay, okay.
segments.answer: That™s what it seems to me, but Œ

segments.question: The other question that comes to mind, an d again this is in Œ in my mind an irony because I wouldn™t Œ I™m not as familiar with the history at the time, is why would Poland be someone you™d be Œ th ere would be more of such negative feelings about than the Soviet Union , which is right next door? What Œ well, so is Poland, but Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 51but what kind of discussions were going on, what kind of sensibility was there about the Soviet Union? What role did that play in Panevžys , you know, and what was going on? What did you know of what was going on in Soviet Russia , and the union itself?
segments.answer: We knew some, we knew the Œ you know, my ma Œ my f Œ my father see the beginnings of the Russian revolution in Russia. I would say so. Again, the Polish thing. Soviet Union was supporting Lithuania in this Polish Lithuanian conflict. Or supporting Lithuania™s claim to Vilnius.

segments.question: All along?
segments.answer: All along. The only one of the great powers. The Germans also didn™t recognize the Polish annextion of Vilnius, but the Germans were not willing to, you know, to take stand, or support Lithuania or something like that. So they kept more or less outside of that Œ of that issue. The Great Britain, France, Italy, Japan supported Poland . So the only great power supporting Œ United States were behind the area, you know, they didn™t Œ it was time of isola tion, they didn™t Œ tried not to take any stance in European affairs at all. So the only real power supporting Lithuania was Soviet Union . Now, my parents, being good Ca tholics and Lithuanians, they disapproved of the communist system as such. But there was little discussion of that, you know, all of the memories of revolution as my father said, I mean he thought that revolution was, of course, a cruel peri od of time. A lot of things happened, but Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 52he thought that, you know, after all this time, there was some Œ some normality in the country. Even he didn't wanted to be lieve that there was a constant terror or something like that. Although, you know, w-we read about the terror in Œ against so-called, you know, the Œ the short trials of the c Œ other communists against Stalin , and Œ

segments.question: You read that in the Lithuanian media?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, that was Œ so di Œ that was looked Œ people didn™t believe really that all those people, you know, were traitors or something like that, and there was going a struggle for power. But as far as Lithuania is concerned, that was outside of our real concerns.

segments.answer: N-Not Œ we didn™t know a thing about it, no.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Nothing at all.

segments.question: In the 30s, as this was Œ
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay, okay. So Œ so in other words, from what I get Œ a sense I get from you is the Soviet Russia, or Soviet Union was rather benign in it Œ in a Œ in a Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 53
segments.answer: That Œ that was our Œ our impression, mo -most of pre Œ impression of my parents, of the people they Œ they befriended, they discussed those things, yes, that was Œ that did p Œ it was, you know, a Œ was supporting us.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: For our right cause, we imagined that the Lithuanian cause was Œ

segments.question: The right one.
segments.answer: Œ a right cause, so Œ

The Jewish people, and the Lithuanian people who were committed to Lithuanian cause became refugees. They didn™t want Œ and Panevžys, they came even to Panevžys , the Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 54people. And there were appeals, you know, that Œ you know, for living space, for other things, for jobs for those refugees. So my parents decided, you know, that we had a nice house, it was our own house. We have too much space, we can Œ we could rent, you know, the upstairs, you know, to somebody. And we rent it to a girl who came from Klaipda as a refugee, and well, simply, we Œ he Œ she worked in Œ in Œ in Misetas(ph) co-company, you know.

segments.answer: As a clerk, you know, as a clerk, you know, so th-that was a refugee, we came to our Œ to our house. segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Œ you know, who came from Klaipda.

segments.question: Okay, so wa Œ so it was still sort of se parate communities, it was not an integrated sense of these are all Lithuanian citizens, but it was more, each takes care of its own.

Hitler himself came to Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 56Klaipda, you know, and well, was a very sad moment for Lithuania, but we felt that™s Œ it was a superior Œ superior power, couldn™t do much about it.

segments.answer: Gates of Dawn Œ

And [indecipherable] thing, and so Lithuanian students met our excursion, and he was a lead er of our excursion, so the city told about how Lithuanians lived u nder the Poles, you know, a nd we went to Lithuanian s-s Œ girls™ school, the girls Œ the Œ it was summer, so the girls went home, so the school was empty, so Œ but they accommodated us. segments.question: Okay.

But there were also the signs all over the Vilnius that Œ in Polish Œ that we are not going to retreat from our seashore. And they were Œ they were ready to fight. segments.answer: And she knew German, and she knew, you know, that the war is coming, but he Œ she didn™t think, you know, about all those horrible things. So Œ so what, you know? What Œ what are the Germans going to do to me, you know? Well, nothing, you know. It doesn™t matter, you know, so Œ

segments.question: Yeah.

segments.answer: Th Œ that Œ I Œ I was just Œ

segments.answer: Yes.

segments.answer: That™s right, but af-after Œ after visit to Vilnius I became political.

segments.answer: And then the school started September fi rst, and the war started, of course, and that was news, and everybody was liste ning to the radio, and everybody was following what™s going on, and quite soon it was clear, you know, o-of the German superiority, which we thought even before. I didn™t see it, but other people saw the German army in Klaip da. We saw Polish army in Œ in Vilnius, and it was obvious, you know, that the Germans were much be tter prepared, and much stronger army than the Poles, and even before the war started, we thought that the Poles are going to lose the war. And of course, we Œ we kids, you know, were, because of that hostility with the Poles, we thought that™s Œ that™s a nice time for Lithuania to recover Vilnius . The Germans are attacking Poland and pole Œ Polish army Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 68definitely is losing, like in the first days it was quite obvious a German attack was, you know, the Blitzkrieg. They Œ they went very, very strongly wi-with air Œ air attacks, armored formations. So we thought well, you know, why Lithuanian army doesn™t go there and recover Vilnius, because Poles will be not able to resist any more.

segments.question: Was there any sentiment of changing, I mean any voices amongst Lithuanians that said well, maybe we didn™t like the Poles very much for what they did, but my God, what™s happening in Poland, and it™s terrible? Was that Œ was there any sympathy being expressed in the so Œ in those circles that you were in, of Poland™s getting it now, and it™s Œ it™s not easy?
segments.answer: Not in the those circles I was in.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Not in my co Œ friends, classmates, no. Not in my family. But, our director of-of our school told us Germans are not going to win this war. It is world war, and the Germans are going to lose, and we shouldn™t interfere in the war now. He didn™t say that, you know, he Œ he simp Œ in sympathy with Poles or something. Maybe he was, I don™t know. But he was convinced that the Nazis are going to lose. And it seems like not some kind of a military or Œ or Œ or economical anal ysis, but because the Nazi ideology, that generation knew Germans from the first occupation during the first World War. And they were convinced that the Germans were always overdoing. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 69

segments.question: Overreaching themselves?
segments.answer: Overreaching. In the first World War, and from the Nazi ideology they deducted that the Nazis are ric Œ ready to do the same thing, to overreach more, even more than the Œ during the first World War. So they were Œ and our president, Antanas Smetona also was of that opinion. Some of th e officers of Lithuanian army, some o-of the diplomats said, I mean , it™s a chance to recover Vilnius, let™s go, and Germans were encouraging Lithuanians, encouraging, you know, that wil Œ Lithuania wil Œ would go and recover Vilnius. And the British said, in that case, Great Britain will declare war against Lithuania . But well, now this is the question, who will de Œ will win the war, and Smetona was convinced that Germans are going to lose, and he didn't Œ we didn™t know about that tim e, but we knew, you know, later, that Smetona was against that, and that™s why Lithuania didn™t Œ didn™t attack Poland at that time, because of Smetona and of thinking, which ou r director told to us [indecipherable]

segments.question: Would you say, you know, would you say your family belonged to a particular kind of political wing in Lithuania , or was it fairly typical of, let™s say the mood in society? From what I understand there was a Christian democrat, and a more nationalist, or national political forces.
segments.answer: Right. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 70

segments.question: Which one would your family would have Œ thought they would have identified with more?
segments.answer: My father was close to Christian democrats.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: But he didn™t belong to the party. And later he drifted closer to this national movement of Smetona, of the president, but he was also critical of Smetona quite a b Œ a bit, but Œ but he was like in between those two. Now, from my mother™s side, everybody was Smetona™s.

segments.question: So they were much more of a Œ of Œ from the national Œ
segments.answer: Yes, from Œ

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Œ starting from my grandfather, through all those brothers, you know, everybody, including my mother was from the national group of [indecipherable]

segments.question: Would you have cal led them nationalists?
segments.answer: Translating would be, yes, but they were not any kind of Nazis, they were anti Œ anti Nazi, anti-German. And there were, you know, some Œ s-some who Œ wh-who were pro-German, and pro-Nazi , like Waldemartas (ph) and so, but i-it Œ it Œ Smetona was hostile to that Œ

segments.question: Yes. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 71
segments.answer: Œ that type of thinking, and Œ and those who followed Smetona was hostile against the Nazi thinking, not only as Œ as German, but generally against Nazi and fascist things. Fascism of Italian type had more sympathies. There were not too many, but Italians type was closer. There was no racism in Œ in Italy, in Œ at least at the beginning, na Œ and Œ so, but in Œ in Œ in our circle s, no, you know, there was no Œ no sympathy for the Nazis.

segments.question: And yet Œ and yet, there was temptation Œ
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Œ that Œ that this Œ this, let™s say encouragement, on be half of the Nazis to then take Vilnius Œ
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Œ was tempting. It wasn™t Œ it wasn™t something that was dismissed as we just don™t do that, unless fa Œ is Œ until Smetona said so.
segments.answer: Right. Smetona, well, is not Œ he is not the onl y one. Also, as I said, our Œ director of our school also was of that opinion, and Œ and there was other people, older people who said, you know, don™t do that. Now, even if Lithuania would have attacked Vilnius, that doesn™t mean that it would be pro-Nazi because he is all Œ th-the Soviet Union supported Lithuania in the Polish-Lithuanian Œ

segments.question: Conflict. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 72
segments.answer: Œ conflict, and here also, you know, Lithuanian Œ Germany would have became Œ become allies for that moment, but lith Œ from Lithuanian viewpoint it would be just like alliance between Finns and Germans, you know. Not Œ they Œ Finns didn™t became Nazis at all, they were allies during the second World War with the Germans, but they still were a democratic country, and had nothing to do with the Nazi ideology at all. So that was the idea. Of course, it was unrealistic. If Œ if would have happened, of course, Nazis would ha ve taken everything that Œ but the hope was that, you know, well, so we are allies, just like we were allies with the Soviets, now we™re allies with the Germans. But S-Smetona was against that, Smetona was a very strong leader, maybe a d Œ we could call it dictator, and without him, you know, nothing Œ nothing happens.

segments.question: Okay. So Œ so the Molotov-Ribbentrop pact is Œ is Œwhat y ou hear of is between non-aggression between the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: That™s what becomes [indecipherable]
segments.answer: That™s what we knew, and there was [indecipherable] so nobody kne-knew about them.

segments.question: Okay. So what happens later, in the early fall, as things progress, and Œ wha Œ how does life in Panevžys change? Or does it? Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 73
segments.answer: Yes, of it Œ it does. First of all, the war, you know, the Œ some of the things, the commerce became affected. There were some Lithuanian ships which were ru-run on the mines, and we Œ one of the sailors, a brother of our classmate came back, I mean his ship was sunk in the Baltic Sea because ran on the mine. It™s Œ

segments.question: It hit a mine. It hit a mine.
segments.answer: Well, hit a mine, well, there were non-contact mines also, you know at that time.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But that™s a technical thing, so anyway, I mean th-the ship was blown out of the Œ

segments.question: Of the water.
segments.answer: Œ of the water, right. So, you know. And then of course Œ and of course the ca Œ the concern whether Lithuania could become Œ still be ne Œ neutral when such a gr-great war is starting around. And when the Soviets attacked Poland also, from the east, then everybody became concerned what™s Œ what™s now. Because the Soviets are taking over all the eastern portion of Poland Œ well, really the Ukrainians, Byelorussians and Lithuanians living there, but doesn™t matter, you know, it™s Œ was still Poland . They took Vilnius, the Soviets, and now, y ou know, everybody became Œ now we are involved. Soviets recognize Vilnius as Lithuania™s capital, now they Œ are they going to turn it over to us, or will they find, you know, some kind of thing to Œ to get out of it, of the Œ the commitment. And there was mobilization. There was declared, you know, the Lithuanian army was mobilized to protect its neutrality, not Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 74for war. But the Polish army, you k now, went over the boundary to Lithuania and was disarmed, so they had Œ Lithuania army had to be there to disarm the Polish army coming over, and to intern them as the neutral country™s supposed to do in such case. And a lot of Polish military came ove r, and refugees Œ generally refugees, not military refugees from Poland came to Lithuania, and they found quite Œ quite a bit of understanding and sympathy then, you know. Poland was defeated and broken and then, you know, it seemed like, you kn ow Œ not Œ not an enemy any more you had to fight, you know. So the Œ there was sympathy for them and Œ and Œ and all the routine mobilization, we thought wi Œ the Lithuanian army being mobilized that they will go to Vilnius. And we Œ we were all, in our class I think everybody was, you know, why our army is not going there? But as I said, the director explained to us, we didn't believe him, but that™s what it was, the older gene ration decided it would be foolish to get into that war. And Œ but then we were very much tol Œ concerned, what will be next, you know, everybody was concerned. There was organization, so-called Sauliai (ph).

segments.question: What is it? How would you translate it?
segments.answer: It is close to national guard, p-partly like a reserves, part like national guard. There was a military people a-after they served in the army, they were released into reserves, and they voluntar ily joined that organization, which was a military organization, but not quite. It differs, for instance, from the na tional guard in that Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 75was Œ that he Œ they had also cultural thing. They had dances, they had lectures also, you know.

segments.question: So it was somewhat civic?
segments.answer: Somewhat civic, yeah. But it was very popular, a lot of people in the Œ men, and also women belonged to that organization. And it™s also part Œ was part of the Œ of the country™s military capa Œ ca Œ capacity, and so Œ a nd we were a-also our Œ the students of Œ in the high school, in the higher classes, now also belonged to that organization. I belonged too, voluntarily, whoever wanted, there was no pressure at all to join, but I joined it. And we were also called to duty then.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Then the mobilization came and we were sent to Œ on the guard duty in Œ in the city as a Œ I™m writing in my memoirs, there will be no Œ our students were not quite military minded at all, you know, they might have m-ma de Œ made a Œ a Œ a play out of it, and it was a serious thing, so we Œ we were removed from the guard duty and sent to a place where there were no people.

segments.question: Well, what do you mean by made a play out of it, they Œ they Œ
segments.answer: Well, they were starting, the girls were going to Œ to the school o-on Œ through the bridge Œ the bridge, they were supposed to guard the bridge. They started on, you know, ch-checking their bags and all that ki nd of thing, and it was a flirt really. And it was Œ and when Œ when th e leaders found out, they we re terrified. They said, I Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 76mean, the p Œ the parents will complain, so we will go before court martial for this thing, you know. So they took off of Œ of duty us completely and sent to guard gasoline tanks and Œ and outside place. They want Œ

segments.question: Where there were no girls whose bags you could check.
segments.answer: No girls, no. And no people at all, just a gr-great, friendly dog who came to visit us, that™s all.

segments.question: Okay. So that is how, in the early fall, things seemed to be developing.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: What happens next?
segments.answer: Well, mobilization was called off, we came back to our classes. Our cl Œ school was taking over for Œ for military ca Œ no, the girls™ school was taking over for the Œ the military. The girls went to our school in the daytime, we went during the nighttime to our school, because it was different schools, girl and Œ and boys™ school. And Œ but it was a short period of tim e, and of course there was news that, you know, Lithuania is recovering Vilnius, Soviets are letting have Vilnius for Lithuania . Not all the territory which Lithuania claimed and the Soviets recognized before, you know, they Œ they just returned a quarter of the territory, but with the capital city. And also was news that, you know, the military bases, Soviet military bases will be introduced in Lithuania. The Soviets will have military bases in Lithuania. So, everybody was really happy that Vilnius is returning to Lithuania, Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 77and everybody was concerned that the Soviet army is being introduced in Lithuania and having bases here. It was not a big surprise really, because before that Estonia and Latvia already were forced. They didn™t get anything, bu t they had to take in Soviet bases, Soviet guard [indecipherable]

segments.question: Did you know that in Panevžys at the time?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, that was in the news , in the newspapers, everybody. So , Estonia first, Latvia second, Lithuania after that.

segments.question: Do you know Œ was there a sense, did you Œ was there any discussion or did you have a feeling about Œ I™m doing all of this as a preface, what the Jewish community was thinking, how people in the Jewish community were reacting to these events, the local Jewish community in Panevžys. Was there any Œ any knowledge Œ I mean, I Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 78don™t have a sense that you know, was much contact, but did you Œ do you remember anything about that?
segments.answer: Well, personally I didn't have, at that tim e, connections. We had Jewish friends in our Œ in our class, but Œ a nd one was fairly close to me, but we somehow didn™t discuss much about this situation. But it was from my parents™ contacts, we knew that, of course the Jews were concerned about the German attack, and the German strength, which they showed, you know, and the power. And of course everybody knew how hostile the Nazis are against Œ against the Jews. So, the concern was quite stunder Œ understandable. But that™s Œ that ™s about Œ about it. I mean, there were concern, but Œ

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Œ I don™t know. Of course they Œ they were not in favor that Lithuania would attack Poland, you know, but [indecipherable] they didn™t.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So Œ so it seemed Œ so I Œ I don™t know. I could transfer my [indecipherable]

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I had no Œ

segments.question: Okay. So, when we™re talking about th ose military bases, you Œ you get the news in school. Do you remember how you got the news that Vilnius is going to come back into Lithuanian control, do you remember where you were? Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 79
segments.answer: Oh, everybody was at Œ at the radios at that time.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We [indecipherable] the Lithuanian delegation, government delegation was in Moscow.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: So we knew that it will be decided one way or the other, and so everybody was just glued to the radio and listening wh en the end Œ when it was announced, you know, the news, and eventually it was, you know, that this Œ the treaty between Lithuania and Soviet Union is signed and Vilnius is really Œ really turned to Lithuania , and the military garrisons will be introduced in Lithuania, Soviet military.

segments.question: What date was this, do you remember?
segments.answer: It was, yeah, it was 1939, October 10th was they signed the treaty and we knew about that October 11th, in the morning, from the radio.

segments.question: From the radio.
segments.answer: Yeah, and then, of course, newspape rs. And the newspapers were a great disappointment because they showed new boundary between Lithuania and the Soviet Union , and as I said, I mean, just a quarter of the territory was being returned to Lithuania, three-quarters was just kept, Stalin for themself. And the problem is that the Lithuanian areas were the farmers, and generally the population was Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 80Lithuanian in that area. They fell to the Œ to th Œ to the Soviet side, you know. Lithuania didn™t receive even those territories which were ethnically Lithuanian.

segments.question: Are these Œ was this part of Belarus, where these Œ
segments.answer: It became part of Belarus then.

segments.question: Œ [indecipherable] Belarus , mm-hm.
segments.answer: Par Œ became part of Belarus. Later the boundary was adjusted when Lithuania was occupied, but the areas like Druskininkai, like −venionys, they were part of Belarus Œ Belarus at that time.

segments.question: So you got bad Œ good news, bad news basically Œ
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Œ October 11 th.
segments.answer: That™s right, that™s right. So the Œ the enthusiasm was Œ was k-kind of muted at that point, and there was a meeting, you know, and i-it was muted, until really the Soviets Œ Soviets kept Vilnius for a couple of weeks yet, and they were r-really plundering the ke Œ the city during that tim e, and eventually the Lithuanian army took over Vilnius. And s-somehow you know, at that point, when Lithuanian army marched into Vilnius, the country became split personality, the people said now we are going to celebrate, we are going to worry tomorrow. Everybody knew that there is a lot of to Œ something to worry, but to day we are celebrating, tomorrow we are Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 81are g Œ are going to worry. And that™s what we did, we celebrated and then we started to Œ to worry right away after that, after the celebration.

segments.question: And Œ okay, so now Lithuania™s in Vilnius.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Did you Œ when was the first time you saw a Soviet soldier?
segments.answer: Oh, that was an accident, the Œ well, again, after Lithuania Œ the Soviets had called the government delegation from Finland in Œ into Moscow and started discussions with the Finns, and they had also, you know, demands, which the Finns re Œ refused. So, in Œ in a month™s time the Soviets attacked Finland and became Finnish Winter War. And now everybody was for Finns in Lithuania . Soviet Union was supposed to be our ally, and well, ally, but we Œ we Œ we still were for the Finns, they were so Œ so heroically defending their country, you just couldn™t help it. Now, one of the Soviet planes was bombing Helsinki, ar Œ or some other Finnish cities, anyway, was one bomb Œ on the bombing ra id. The Finns were shooting back, and the p Œ the pa Œ the plane was damaged, co uldn™t navigate very well, but turned south, went over Estonia, Latvia, came to Lithuania and near Panev žys, crashed. Well, really, crash landed, I would say.

segments.question: Crash landed, okay.
segments.answer: Crash landed. The pilots came out and said, I mean, how far is Riga? Well, they flew over Riga already, but they couldn™t tell any more. So, the Soviets from their Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 82barra Œ from their military bases in Lithuania came, the Soviet soldiers to that place, dismantled the plane and brought it to the ra ilroad station and took it. And we saw then that plane, it went through our gymna sium, through the street in front of us. Everybody was at the Œ at the window, and we saw the plane, all warped by bullets, which wa Œ wa Œ that Œ and we saw Soviet soldiers taking that plane away. So that was the first time we saw the Soviet soldiers, taking away that damaged plane.

segments.question: So y Œ so you Œ the Œ so, in othe r words, the garrison had already been established, but you just hadn™t seen them yet.
segments.answer: No Œ yeah, th-they were Œ th ey were close, they were Œ

segments.question: They were close.
segments.answer: Œ they were Œ they were not Œ not Œ not going to be Œ to the streets or anything like that. There were Œ there were garrisons who were there, but they were closed.

segments.question: Closed.
segments.answer: They didn™t let their soldiers room around Œ roam around at all.

segments.question: Okay. And that plane is what you see, a nd it™s in Œ and it™s in bits and pieces, and it goes by your school window, and it™s of great curiosity to everybody.
segments.answer: Yes, yeah.

segments.question: Okay. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 83
segments.answer: Yeah. Also a bittersweet thing, because you know, w-we like to see the Œ the plane warped by the Finnish bullets, but then the so Œ Soviet soldiers in Lithuania was, you know, a bitter part of it.

segments.question: This is a continuation of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Algimantas Gureckas on October 14 th, 2010. Mr. Gureckas, where we left off, you were describing to us how you saw the downed Soviet plane which had fought Œ which was flying against Œ in the Finnish Œ the Winter War against Finland, how it landed near Panevžys, and you saw the dismantled parts of it being taken by Soviet soldiers, and it aroused a great deal of curiosity amongst the Œ the kids in school, and you all went to the windows to take a look. I wanted to ask a question about, let™s say, how kids felt then when these events were happening. And bring it back to the very beginning of tens ions. Did you, as Œ as young students have an urge to do something, whether it was agai nst the Germans, or against the Poles, or against the Soviets, to defend your country? Were there any such student types of discussions or ideas going on, or even actions that were taken?
segments.answer: Well, I could tell about one really ridicu lous thing, because we were 15 years old when the Œ there was a tension about Klaip da, a problem, the Germans were pressing Lithuania at that time, and it was clear that they will, sooner or later will demand that Lithuania return Klaipda, together with the Klaip da territory to Germany. So my classmate, and my close friend, he told me that he heard a rumor that there is no organization, but secretly Lithuanian army is mobilizing, taking the volunteers, registering the volunteers, and he Œ he kind of suggested that we might Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 85be interested in that. So I Œ I said yes. My father was fighting for Lithuania , now it™s my turn, y-you know. And we we nt together with him to Œ

segments.question: Did you tell your father?
segments.answer: No, of course not. That would be the en d of the story. No, we went together with him to the military office in Panev žys , and just asks whether, you know, they Œ they need any voluntaries to fight for Lithuania. Well, the sergeant there was kind of a Œ excited. I mean, he was Œ he wa s dumbfounded really, you know. And we couldn™t understand why Œ why he was you know, so kind of confused. We just wanted to fight for Lithuania , that™s all, that seems so Œ and he, an elderly sergeant, you know, was a pr Œ now I can see, you know, why Œ why he was Œ the children want fight for Lithuania, well Œ but that was the end of the story. They said no, thank you, you know. If we need we will call on you, and we™ll call nev Œ everybody. But now Œ now, we don™t need your service. But good Œ good boys, you know, grow up. You will be good soldiers someday. Okay, so we went back to class, and somehow, apparently my friend told ma Œ our Œ our friend Rubinsteinas (ph), a Jewish friend. He was one of our gang, Shalamas (ph) Rubinsteinas(ph), and he Œ apparently my friend told him about that st ory, and he was all upset that we didn™t take him with th Œ with Œ with us. He also wanted to fight Germans.

segments.question: Wanted to fight. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 86
segments.answer: Yeah, so that was the oh Œ the only rea lly disagreement we had with him i-in our Œ in our friendship. So Œ so that™s Œ that™s the story. After that, of course, we were i-in that organ Œ organization, −auliai , I would call like national guard. And we took seriously our duties, you know, wh enever we were called upon.

segments.question: To check the girls™ bags.
segments.answer: Y-Yeah, well that™s Œ I didn™t do that.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I was supposed to be responsible for that guard, and I didn™t check on Œ on it. But yeah, yeah, so on.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: That™s like that.

segments.question: But there was Œ was there any such talk Œ did it ever Œ first of all, did this story Œ this event ever reach your parents™ ears?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We didn™t tell that.

segments.question: Okay. And number two, did Œ did anythi ng similar happen with Œ with Poles or with lith Œ with the Soviets, or anything else that was developing at the time? Was there any other talk amongst the kids in sch ool of any sort of resistance or activity, or anything like that about things Œ these histor Œ these [indecipherable] Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 87
segments.answer: No, n-nothing against the Po les. I mean, the thing went too f Œ too fast. We didn™t Œ we didn™t even realize what the ultimatum was ac-accepted, you know. And I was sick at that time at home, you know, so I Œ I don™t know how my friends reacted, and Œ at school. But no, this thing beca me only when the Soviets occupied Lithuania, then Œ then we found tha-that we have to resist that somehow. And that™s another part of my story, you know, wh en a Œ when the Soviets annex Lithuania, occupied and annexed Lithuania . Yeah, I was looking for a place, you know, I could join some resistance group. And the only group I knew was the Catholic organization, adate Œ

segments.answer: Adaytis(ph)

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Adaytis(ph), and this organization was illegal under the independent Lithuania , Smetona™s regime, because they Œ it was legal in the universities, but not in the Œ in the high schools, because Smetona™s regime thought that it™s too early to get into political things. [phone ringing]

segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: So let™s go back to October, when the bases appear, yo-you hear the news, the Molotov-Ribbentrop pact, the bases appear, the plane is down, you see the Œ the parts going on. How did life change after that? How di Œ did it Œ did you feel it impact you in any way when those bases first arrived?
segments.answer: No, the things quieted down. While the Soviets were fighting against the Finns, they didn™t put any pressure on Lithuania . The bases were there, you know, but there were no conflicts as far as we were conc Œ you know, aware. And it seemed like, you know, we were a gr Œ very upset and apprehensive i-in the fall, about October, November. But in the springtime of 1940, it looked like the things quieted down.

segments.question: Life hadn™t changed much.
segments.answer: The life, they didn™t change much. Of course, war was going on, as I said, you know, and there were Œ there were less selection in the Œ in the Œ in the Œ in the m Œ on the market because of the blockades, you know. But life was going pretty normal by that time.

segments.question: So th Œ the government Œ what had happened to Mr. Smetona, President Smetona? Did he stay around? Was he still president?
segments.answer: Yes, he was still president. Government was fank Œ functioning as it always did. It seemed like the things quieted down. Of course, we were following war. The Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 89Germans were landing in Scandinavia , in Denmark , and Norway , and then, you know, they attacked in the west, a-and Œ through Netherlands, Belgium and France, and the big battles of 1940 was going in the west. So everybody was following what™s going on, because it was Œ

segments.answer: At that time Lithuanian b Œ was suffici ent. We got from Lithuanian newspapers, Lithuanian radio the information. Of c ourse, other s Œ radio stations, German, Russian and others were available, but we didn™t Œ we didn™t feel like we have to use that at that time.

segments.answer: Well, the occupation. Because Œ

segments.answer: Oh yeah, the bases were limited in certain places, and they were closed, they didn™t let their soldiers roam around, you know, they were all in Œ in the bases. And Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 90suddenly, you know, the Soviet army Œ well, as a Œ as I told, I mean, I Œ my father came Œ we knew that our government delegation is in Moscow, there are some kind of problems there, but nobody thought it™s a great deal. And then suddenly my father came from somewhere, called me, and said, you know that the Soviets are occupying the country, taking over the country. And that™s what happened, and that Œ

segments.answer: It was already vacation started, you know, and then it was June, and vacation started, classes were over. And my father were all upset, and excited, and I had my friend with me. And he said, let Œ let the friend go. So I said, oh, my Œ my father has something to Œ

segments.question: Who was this friend?
segments.answer: Œ for me to do. Well, it was a younger boy from the high school, and Œ but two classes lower, because he was younger. He was just Œ just as a Œ his relationship was strange. He was related to the Polish Marshall Pilsudski, who was Œ died Œ who died by Œ by that time he was dead. But he was related through his Œ his mother side, you know. And I don™t know whether he consider ed himself Pole or Lithuanian, but he Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 91was also very much interested in politics, in wa Œ in th-the war going on here. We came, we discussed those things. I was ki nd of try to be diplomatic, you know, I didn™t show my an Œ our hostility Œ

segments.question: Anti [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Œ to the Polish, you know, and I tried to be diplomatic, and then my father came and said let Œ let him go, and then I said, my father has something to do, has a task. And then my father said, you know, the Soviets are occupying Lithuania. And that was in the afternoon. Night, we slept during the night. During the night the Soviet troops came from Vilnius, it took Vilnius first and went to Panevžys , and started Œ well, then the tanks, th-the Œ the motorized troops, you know, were going Œ it Œ it was not a Œ a garrison, it was not a base. It wa Œ they were all over the place. And a Œ taking over, you know, and taking over the military establishments in Lithuania , taking hi Œ the barracks, the Œ

segments.answer: Well, the next morning we came up, they were already went through Panevžys , they were in the ba Œ in the military barracks somewhere, and they went farther from Panevžys over Ciulai . We still saw some tanks, some military cars going, you know, on the road, but not ma Œ the mass, which was before, you know, during the night. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 92

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: I didn™t see that Œ that massive movement, it was during the night, and somehow I didn™t hear it, and Œ although there should have been some Œ some noi Œ a lot of noise, but somehow I slept well. And that™s it. And wi Œ

And Œ well, it™s difficult to say, but you know, there were also reports in the radio, in the press that the president has left Lithuania, he fled Lithuania , so he was condemned that he didn™t stay with his country during the critical time, and all that kind of thing, and this Œ

segments.answer: Still the Lithuanian press, it seemed like Lithuanian press, but apparently the control was already in Œ in the Soviet hands, or at least in the communist Œ Lithuanian communist party™s hands.

segments.question: Mm-hm. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 93
segments.answer: Yeah, so Œ and Œ and then, you know, that same day, it was Sunday. Saturday there was the ultimatum and they marched into Lithuania and in Panevžys Sunday afternoon, I saw the first communist demonstration in Panevžys in the main square. The people didn™t Œ didn™t walk the streets. It was Sunday and the city was kind of empty. I went to s Œ into this Œ the city to take a look at what ™s going on. Nothing. Were Œ were very few people going dur Œ during the streets, in the streets. Not like a regular Sunday. And then I went to the main square and there was a demonstration, not a big one, maybe 50 - 60 people there.

segments.answer: Mostly young, I would say, mostly young people. And they were Œ had the red flag there, and they were speaking in Lithuanian, you know, against the sovi Œ Smetona government, against the Œ the w hole system, against the fascist government, as they called here Œ Smetona™s government. And the others were listening to that, and j-just seemed like all of them Œ of the people were Jewish.

segments.answer: Well, typically from Œ from the racial features, and from the accent the speakers used. The listeners, of course, I don™t know. Well, I didn't check all, I was kind of aside, you know, I wasn™t in the demonstration itself. So it™s difficult to say, you know, the composition, but it Œ the impression was like most of them or even all of Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 94them were Jewish. Now, my fa Œ the Jew Œ the communist party was illegal in Lithuania before that. Even when the Œ when the bases came in, it still was illegal. My father was working in the court system, and some of the Œ of the clients, as he called, he had some communists also, who were accused just of the communist activities. And so he was concerned that now, you know, that things changed, and those communists will became very influential. And Œ

segments.answer: Yeah, he had a negative opinion, b ecause one of the Œ of the important communists which he was exim Œ examining his activities, was from a very rich Jewish family in Panevžys.

segments.answer: From very rich Œ pardon?

segments.question: Do you remember their name?
segments.answer: No, I wouldn't, but I Œ I could find, beca use he was important later on, so maybe I could find out later, but I don™t remember exact now. And so i-i Œ even that, you know, for him looked kind of ridiculous or Œ or Œ or unacceptable that from such a rich family, you know, he becomes co mmunist, and is working against the Lithuanian government, really. And I must say, later he was concerned that he will Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 95become imp Œ im Œ important person, which was right, he became very important person. But became not in Panevžys, but in Vilnius.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: I ent Œ the Œ the story is interesting. He was afraid that there will be some revenge. There was nothing from that. He didn™t Œ

segments.question: Who was Œ who was afraid there would be revenge?
segments.answer: My father.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: My father was afraid that they Œ he will re Œ take revenge against him because he was conducting that investigation. But there was none.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: He was Œ he was in Vilnius, he was doing his Œ communists were there, you know, and whatever, and there was none. But there were some other people, you know, who take revenge, mostly criminals.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Who also thought, I mean, they might be Œ so, th-they had the problem there, but this communist wasn™t Œ he just ignored.

data: So when you s Œ okay, when you sa w this demonstration, what Œ do you remember what your feelings were at the time? Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 96

I was afraid. I was afraid that the revolution is going on, from what I heard what happened in Russia, you know, with all the cruelties of the revolution might happen right Œ right here, right now, you know, in Œ in Panevžys . They decided Œ they decided that they sh Œ you know, they should go and disp erse the police, this Œ the fash Œ fascist police, as they said. And they Œ they march with their red flag, they march toward police, I didn™t follow them, and I f Œ later find out that the Lithuanian military officer in Panev žys telephoned the Soviet forces, whichever the commander was in Panevžys, and asks whether, you know , that™s supposed what™s Œ what should happen, because they were trying to Œ to disperse the police, you know, and take the po lice headquarters in Panev žys . And the Soviet commander said no, no demonstrations, nothing is allowed, and if you don™t Œ if you don™t protect the quiet in Œ in the city, we will have to take care of it and provide this Œ this Œ so th-there would be no d Œ no demonstrations, nothing . So then, you know, h-he co Œ the c Œ the commandant, the Lithuanian officer called −auliai, and we were also called, I Œ oh, we went to the −auliai headquarters, we have given rifles, and we were supposed Œ there was Œ commandant™s hour, was supposed to enforce that, to patrol the streets, and see that nobody walks during the nighttime, which we Œ

segments.answer: Which we did, yeah. I did, and my fri ends did. That was quite Œ nobody was demonstrating nothing, n obody was walking around. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 97

segments.answer: No, no, no.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: Not at all.

segments.answer: No, not Œ not real communists. There were people, very leftists, you know, opinions, one Œ one Œ one Œ one doctor, he was a friend of the family. He Œ he had very favorable opinion, but he wasn ™t communist, he wasn™t working for the party or anything like that, so.

segments.question: Did anything Œ do you know what happen ed to him when this Œ there was the fo Œ the Soviet occupation? Did his [indecipherable] change?
segments.answer: He became director of the Œ of the hospital.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And then I think he expanded that hospita l very well. He Œ he would Œ as Œ as a doctor he was really, you know , valued under the system. But I Œ I su Œ suspect momore than a doctor than Œ than a co Œ I don™t think he was really a communist, even Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 98after Œ in particular after he saw, you know, the communism in Œ you know, in Œ in real life.

segments.question: I want to go back again to that demons tration. You said you were scared. Did you have any view of Œ did you have any Œ any thoughts ab out the demonstrators? You know, why they were demonstrating? Were you surprised to see it? Were you Œ
segments.answer: I was surprised, but I understood that there Œ there are communists, so we Œ we knew my father said that there [indecipherable] are the young, some young Jewish people, the communists wi Œ is popular be tween some young Jewish peop Œ men and Œ and la Œ and girls. This Œ this group was small group, and apparently that™s Œ that™s the limit at that time.

segments.answer: Well, demonstrations. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 99

segments.answer: Oh yeah, well Œ but those were official s, you know. The peopl e had to go into demonstrations. From their working places they were told that they better go, you know, and there was a threat, unconcealed threat that si Œ they will take care of all those who are against the people™s government, as they say. And Œ

segments.question: That when there was the Finno-Russian war, then you were on the side of the Finns because you know, they were the weaker, or the Œ it was their territory that was being attacked, and so it was more that you were on their side than the Soviet side. segments.answer: Beginning was the first Œ the intr Œ i-introduction of the military bases, that Œ that was the first, and then the thing, you get Œ you get deeper. But that Œ that was the first.

segments.question: Okay, so that™s October, 1939.
segments.answer: Yeah. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 100

segments.answer: Right. But even then, before that, go Œ with the World War goin g on, in particular w-with France collapsing, many people were thinking that Lithuania might not be able to survive as independent country. And there was a discussion going on, which is better, that the Germans would take ov er or the Œ or the Russians? Because Po-Poland wa-was gone, you know, was conquered by the Œ by both of them and partitioned. And I would say Œ I was inclined that it ba Œ may be better under the Germans, my opinion. Not very strong, but I was leaning that way. But th Œ I would say the majority of Lithuanians we knew in Œ in the circle, were of the opinion that maybe the Russians occupation would be more benign, because the Russians are not that efficient, not that organized in our opinion.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And Œ and Lithuanian na tion would have a better chance to survive longer Œ long time than under harsh and efficient German oc cupation. So even at that point, people were leaning more toward the Russians than the Germans, more toward the Soviets. Well, the Russians they were call Œ calling at that time, until the occupation itself.

segments.question: And why were you, you kno w, slightly more inclined toward Œ if Œ of Œ of the two evils, the German one would be the lesser?
segments.answer: That™s difficult to say f-for me, I don™t know. Maybe from the times of Taurag, their culture were more familiar to me. And you know, we had very good German Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 101teacher, even a g Œ a German, Lithuanian German in Panev žys , and German culture, maybe made impression on me. I Œ I Œ I like Œ I read Œ I Œ I knew German language fairly well. I started reading German books. Th Œ just that. It wasn™t something very Œ very firm, you know, bu t I would say I was leaning that way.

segments.question: Okay. So it Œ
segments.answer: And the communist system somehow looked inefficient, distasteful. Thi Œ thi Œ I Œ I didn™t realize the amount of Œ of vi olence in the nationa Œ national soc Œ socialistic German [indecipherable] I didn™t re-realize that much, than what I f Œ later found out. And the Soviets were pretty obvious. Once they came in, they were obvious. They wer Œ they we Œ they were threatening. They were not Œ not Œ propaganda was befo re they came in.

segments.question: The pro Œ there was, or there was not propaganda?
segments.answer: There was a lot of propaganda but they didn™t care whether we believed or not Œ

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Œ because the main thing was the threat behind it.

segments.question: Okay, okay. So when they actually occupied Œ
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Œ then that changed? Then they cared that you believed it?
segments.answer: Oh, they cared all the time, but I Œ I don™t know, you know, e-even being friendly to them didn™t mean much, you know? Some ca Œ somehow Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 102

segments.question: Show me Œ explain to me how this thre at made itself felt. Even Œ you know, you have a Œ up to th Œ I have a picture of Sovi ets in the streets, Ru ssian soldiers in the streets, this demonstration, an ideology that™s against the Œ the former independent government and so on. But what makes th is scary? What makes this aggressive?
segments.answer: Well, they started arresting people pr etty soon, you know, I don™t know, ma Œ maybe not the first week, but the second or third week, some of Lithuania™s ministers from the previous government were arrested and brou Œ and not arrested in Lithuania , but arrested and brought to the Soviet Union. And then, just in about a month time, you know, the Œ a lot of people get arrested, including my director of our high school.

segments.answer: Right. Yeah, he was arrested, I Œ a Œ a Œ a good man, you know, we knew, and a lot of other people who were considered, you know, like leading in this society, having influence in the society. There were thousands arrested. And the thing, you know, the Œ there was a prison in Panevžys in the center of the city, built by the tsars, not far from the Œ our house. Our house was in the neighborhood of Œ of that prison. And right there, you know, the prison was Œ had bars in Œ in the windows. Now the bars stayed, but once the Russian s came in, you know, th ey put like some boxes over the windows, so th-they couldn ™t see. Maybe they could see from the Œ one Œ from the top, the Œ the sun, some Œ some light, but they couldn™t see anything Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 103outside. You know, even tho-those small th ings, you know, this Œ that Œ the prison not good enough, they Œ they had to make it much Œ much worse, you know, to isolate people they couldn™t see outside. Yeah, and pretty soon even the Œ from our Œ from our gymnasium, from our Œ not from our class, but you know, they were arrested, even Œ even the students.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Upperclassmen that means, older Œ
segments.answer: Upperclassmen, yeah.

segments.question: Upperclassmen.
segments.answer: Upperclassmen.

segments.answer: Oh yes, yes, yes.

segments.answer: Yeah, one of them was active in that Daiteninkai(ph), that Christian Catholic organization, before Œ appare ntly therefore, he was arrested. Well, the resistance movement started already, so that might be the things they Œ and they were not very par-particular to get exactly their man, you know. And if-if they wanted to get their man, you know, and they didn™t know who it is, so they took 10 of them, thinking Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 104that most likely one of them will be the Œ they are looking for. And that™s it, that™s Œ that was Œ pretty soon we found that that mattered, you know. The terror started pretty soon. Not the first days, but pretty soon. And of course, everything changed. My father lost his job. A lot of people were changed in Œ in governing positions, in Œ even in technical positions. So Œ but no-not only that, but a lot of people were losing their jobs and Œ in the government, and in administration. And everything that, you know, made very oppressive [inaudible]

segments.answer: At that time not yet.

segments.answer: Summer was easy because we went to the Œ on the vacation. Well, I Œ first of all, after this incident in Œ in Œ in Panev žys , when we had to enforce the commandant™s hour, it was vacation time, as far as the school is concerned. So I went to my mother™s farm, which was where she was come from, and her sister was there, you know, running the farm with her husband. A nd so I went there, and I went there because I thought Œ I mean, this Œ this territory might be taken over by the Germans. There were rumors you know, that Œ

segments.question: And you preferred to still, you know Œ yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah, since I preferred to stay wi-with the Germans, you know, I-I thought maybe Œ now I found out th-that not Œ th ere was a division. The Germans were taking Œ supposed to take over part of Lithuania there. But nobody knew exactly, you know, where the Œ the dividing line w ould be. But eventually they didn™t. The Russians took over the Œ the entire country. So, then they went back home and we went on our regular vaca tion with our Œ my uncle in the Œ in the eastern Lithuania in that Œ

segments.answer: With the lakes, yeah.

segments.answer: And wi-wi Œ and with Œ with the boat in the lake and all that. And it was a really quiet place. There was not much going. We heard on the radio, we read in the newspapers all the changes going on in the country.

segments.answer: Y-Yes, it all Œ officially some of them that still had old names, but obviously they were run already by different people appo inted by the new government. So it was a quite Œ we were Œ you know, we were disturbed what Œ about what it was happening, but at that particular place, nothing much was happening. And people were all concerned, everybody was tense. There was supposed to be elections to the people™s parliament, where you know, there were exactly that many candidates as had to be elected deputies. People boy Œ boycotted th-tha t, or even if they voted, they drew, you know, the cartoon characters instead of the bulletins inside. But that was about it, there Œ there was not much, and the meantime they annexed Lithuania. This Œ this parliament was called into the session and accepted the request [indecipherable] Lithuania would be included in the Soviet Union. And we were working with my father in the forest, and came out of the forest into th e small town, and we saw that there were some red flags out, and we asked Œ I mean, what™s Œ what™s now? I mean, what™s new? And ther e was a Œ a smith working at the edge of the town, and we ask him, what Œ what™s now, I mean, why Œ wh y the red flags here? Said, well, they annexed Œ they annexed Moscow to Lithuania . So that was that, Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 107because they annexed Œ announced the annexation. So that was very upsetting, but in that village not much was happening, until, you know, my vacation was over, I came back to Panevžys, and Panevžys there were changes, there were cha Œ

segments.answer: Well, even the Soviet placards ne Œ red, you know, flags everywhere, you know, [indecipherable] . Those Œ those things, let™s see, when Œ when did military took over? Part of our Œ yeah, I think at that time, yeah, th ey Œ they were [indecipherable] . segments.answer: No, I don™t know, he Œ he a Œ she Œ

segments.question: Mm-hm. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 108
segments.answer: So th Œ and they had the small, small gi rl, and they stayed for quite awhile in our Œ in our house. And then another part of the house was taken over and one of the communist leaders, Lithuanian communist le aders were put in that part of the Œ

segments.answer: Not much. First of all, was completely obvious and natural that the Jewish community was glad that Lith-Lithuania was not occupied by the Germans, and if it had to go down, you know, it™s better that the Russians took over. With that, many Lithuanians would have agreed. But now, you know, the Œ the Œ we Œ we noticed pretty soon the hostility against independent Lithuania , against the previous, not only government, but the country itself. No w, it™s very difficult to say how prev Œ prev Œ prevalent this Œ this attitude was. There was definitely some, in particular in the younger generation there. For us Lithuanians, was a gr-great surprise. We never thought that our relations are bad, we never thought that the Jewish people are somehow disadvantaged in Lithuania or Œ or discriminate d against. Yet, the community was kind of separate, jewi Œ but we were Œ we were thinking and werwere convinced that that was the choice of the Jewish community. They wanted to have their own schools, they wanted to have, of course, their religions and synagogues and all that kind of thing, and their organizations. And we didn't mind, but a lot of their life was separate from Lithuanian. There were some Jews which were integrated into Lithuanian society, but there were very few of them.

segments.question: Mm-hm.

Those who were for the Soviet system became very loud. And they wanted to Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 111make, you know, career, to make a do Œ to Œ to advance in this new s Œ new society. So they were a Œ loud, they were active, they were running around. They were tearing off the Lithuanian symbols, you know, from Œ from the houses or wherever they were Œ they were. Those who were against them whether Lithuanian or Jewish or whatever, were kind of subdued. Becau se the terror was there, there was no sense starting, you know, frankly, resisting that, or Œ

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: So those who were against that were quiet and tried to be, you know, not Œ not obvious, you know, with Œ with Œ

segments.answer: Œ their opinions there, so you know. So it™s this Œ that™s why it™s very difficult to say how much of Jewish communi Œ comm unity were collaborating with the Sov Œ Soviet occupation. But it Œ it was obvious that they were , because knew Œ officers knew Œ knew people with responsibility there, a lot of them were Jewish. Not all of them, some of them were Lithuanian communists, but there were not that many Lithuanian communists. All Lithuanian communists got good and significant positions at that time, tasks to do, but there weren't that many of them. And once they ran out of them, also the Jewish people came in and there were Œ there were Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 112more of them, l-lot Œ I Œ I don™t know pe rcentage-wise Œ in numbers wouldn™t be more, but percentage-wise definitely there were more Jewish collaborators than Lithuanian collaborators with the Soviet government. There were also Russians. The Russians also was a split community because part of them were glad that, you know, the Russians were taking over the country. Even the tsarist refugees from the tsarist gov Œ from the Soviet go vernment, who fled to Lithuania said well, it™s Œ th-they might destroy us, you know, the Russians, wh o were against this Œ the Soviets, but it™s still nice that the Russia is expanding again.

segments.answer: Not a ma Œ to Œ i-i-is Œ as somebody told to my father that, exactly.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: A Œ a Russian he knew, you know, friendly. So Œ and so some of them collaborated, but some of them, of course, also tried to just disappear from the view, so not to attract any attention, so that they wouldn™t be, you know, repressed like [indecipherable] or the Œ of the government.

segments.question: Against the Jewish community.
segments.answer: Against the Jewish community.

segments.answer: Œ Soviet system. But how many Œ how in fluential were Œ it was difficult for us to say. Now, my classmate, Rubeinsteinas (ph) Œ our high school or gymnasium was split in two. And Œ

[indecipherable]

And we said, Uditta(ph), why are you afraid, I mean, you Œ you Œ you did nothing, you Œ you were definitely Œ we didn™t even conceive that the Germans would Œ what they did. We couldn™t conceive, we thought, I mean, it™s a Œ it was a civilized nation, you know, a nation of the western civilization. We th ought, I mean Œ well, those who worked for the communists, those, you know, Jewi sh or not Jewish or Lithuanian or whatever, they are in trouble definitely, but Jew Œ Uditta(ph), you know, that wa Œ who Œ who could choo se her, you know?

segments.answer: Nothing. We Œ we tried to tell her, you know, that there is no reason to be afraid, but sh-she just listened and we saw that she Œ she just doesn™t believe us, and she was right. She was right. Yeah, I Œ I remember her, you know, I-I Œ I put Œ when Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 117when they were building this Holocaust Museum, you know, I Œ I asked, you know, that her name would be inscribed in here.

segments.question: Yeah. I go back and I keep wanting Œ

segments.question: Œ you know, I have the same question that I keep asking, which is, and what happened then, and what happened then? Estonia had that, Latvia had that, war was goi ng on, you know, the situation was unclear, how the war will develop was not clear. Somehow it looked too early to start and fight, you know, at that time. It Œ it looked like it™s a right thing to play for time. And that was playing for time, but maybe we™re Œ we™re wrong. I mean, it would be much more effective fighting right Œ right there in 1939, but we were not Finns, we were not that organized like Finns, so Lithuania couldn™t bring defend also, but would be more Œ would be more known, you know, would have attracted more attention in Œ in the world.

segments.question: It s Œ it sounds like what was going on in Moscow, and what people knew in Œ like your family in Panevžys, as plugged in as you were Œ

segments.answer: Right. Yeah, right.

So it Œ when I telling now the story, I have to watch myself to put myself in that time, not what I know now about those Œ the things Œ

segments.answer: Œ because I have read a lot of mate rials about those times, about negotiations, about decisions being taken at that time. Bu t at that time it looked like in 1939, was distasteful and Œ and dangerous, but correct decision to accept the bases, playing for time. But not resisting in 1940, it seemed like the really was Œ was, as I say, betrayal. It was Œ it wasn™t a decision which could be ju stified, really. So when we were trying to fight the Soviets when the Germans attacked, it was desp Œ because Lithuania didn™t resist then, now we have to fight.

segments.answer: No, we don™t want to Œ to be part of the Soviet Union , or of Œ of anything. NoNot of Poland, not for Germany. We want to be independent country. Our parents fo Œ our father fought for that, you know, and we want to have an independent country. That™s Œ that was Œ that was the attitude. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 120

segments.question: This is a continuation of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Algimantas Gureckas on October 14 th, 2010. Mr. Gureckas, I just asked you about what was the year Œ what was the next half year between January and June 1940, what events took place, what things developed, but I thought of another question I wanted to ask, preceding that. And that is, of all these betrayals that we™re talking about: betrayal by the independent Lithuanian government, what was left of it, betrayal by the, you know, small group of let™s say refugees from tsarist Russia, who liked the idea of Russian domination, even if it was with their internal enemies before, betrayal by the Jewish community, or betrayal by Lithuanian Œ Gentile Lithuanians, ethnic Lithuanians, who were communists themselves. Which betrayal do you think you felt in your heart most keenly? Or maybe another betrayal?
segments.answer: No, no. I think the Jewish, because several things. Russian community was so small that it was really insignificant. Our government, pretty Œ find out that there was a split of opinion about that, and there was b-betrayal in the high military command. So Œ also, you know , difficult. Now, Jewish, proble Œ problem is that Œ because maybe we were Œ or were Œ were mistaken, but we had the impression that the Lithuanian Jewish relations are very good. That there is no ispy Œ th-there was some Jewish communists, okay, you know Œ well, more than Lithuanian maybe, Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 122percentage-wise, but that was not rea lly significant. The Jewish community supported Lithuanians in the Vilnius question. They supported Lithuania™s independence, they Œ Smetona had very good relations w ith the Jewish community™s leaders, you know? So we didn™t see the reason why Œ we, as I said, maybe they felt being discriminated, because it was difficult for them, you know, to Œ to Œ you know, to become officers in the army, in the police, and something like that. There was some ethnic discrimination in Lithuania . But those who really wanted could, you know, like Gensis(ph) was an officer in Lithuanian army, and very valued. So there Œ

segments.answer: Yeah, yeah.

segments.answer: Commandant Œ

segments.question: Œ chief of police of Vilnius ghetto.
segments.answer: That™s right, that™s right. He was a Lithuanian officer from the time of the Wars of Independence. He became officer in the Lithuanian military school, and had a very distinguished career in Lith uanian army, in the war with Poland. So, just one example, there were other officers, Jewish officers in Lithuanian army. But benda Œ generally, Lithuania being a small country, just esta blished, and in big tr Œ big conflict with Poland, and with Germany because of Klaipda, were looking Œ they Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 123were discriminating not according to religion or race or anything like that, but about the perceived loyalty to the state. The most discriminated people, of course, were Polish. They just didn™t trust any Pole that he wouldn™t be just a spy, you know, somewhere. So, for pr Œ a Pole got a government sensitive position was practically impossible. Then, of course, Jews, because of some communists in there, you know, in the younger, and because of some cus Œ cosmopolo Œ cosmopolitic approach. A sophisticated approach which Lithuania looked at them kind of s-such small, ridiculous state, you know. They were yus Œ universal peopl e, they Œ they were not Œ not that much ag-gainst Lithuania , but ri Œ but discounting Lithuania. And that also for having some Œ somebody like that in military or police would seem l-like risky, you know, h-h-he doesn™t care about this country. So then, Germans. Lithuanian Germans ou-outside Klaipda were mostly loyal, very loyal, just like I told about that, you know, which I re-reme Œ remember in Taurag, Greigoris(ph), who Œ who refused even to Œ to go to Germany. And the same thing in Panevžys , most of the Germans are loyal, but Germans still, you know, some. And then later, you know, there were Tartars and Karayims, there were no discrimination whatsoever. Their Œ their religion was different, Tartars were Muslim, Karayims had their own religion, Jewish based, you know. The race, you can s-see Karayim, you know, you could see from Œ from the face, from the features. Nim Œ Kara Œ Tartars not so much, was Karayims. But that didn't matter at all. Their people even in Œ in the army made the Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 124career, good career, you know. There were generals, Tartars, there were colonels, Karayims, you know. They were as good or better than Lithuanians, no Œ no problem. So, the base of discrimination was perceived loyalty of the mi-minority.

segments.question: Well that Œ that sort of famous Œ I™m so sorry I interrupted Œ
segments.answer: Yeah, sure.

segments.answer: Yes, yes, yes, yes. And is Œ being, you know, aware that we are Œ the country was, you know, a small country, weak c ountry in Œ in between dangerous other countries. So that was one of the considerations, whether it Œ it was well taken or not, you know, that™s a different thing, but that was the basic feeling. And now, basically, as I said, was the feeling th at the Jewish community was a friendly community and there were not really big conflict. And Œ and the people also, so Œ

segments.answer: Yeah. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 125
