segments.question: Œ have claimed. Do you think that ther e Œ those are Œ outside of any, you know, any events that we™re talking about now, would you say that that has validity to it?
segments.answer: Most likely so. It™s difficult for me to say th Œ because we™re talking about the circle, my circle, my Œ my parents Œ

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Œ my dear friends, my friends, classmates, I didn™t feel that.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: A-A-And all that circle, I din Œ didn™t feel that. Yes, I knew there were some incidents, some i-in between Lithuanian farmers and Œ and Œ an d Jewish merchants, but it Œ yeah, there were so, there was tension between Lithuanians coming into the commercial area, trying to establish their businesses. There is a competition, sometimes this competition went out of bounds, you know, from both sides. The Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 126Jews tried, you know, to es tablish some kind of mo-mon opoly, and push out Œ that Lithuanian out. Li-Lithuanian also, you know, appealing to some anti-se Œ anti-Semitic, you know, feelings. So, apparently there was, but I couldn™t tell ma Œ much because it was way beyond my circle. In my circle that Œ this Œ this wasn™t felt at all.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yeah, there were some Œ for instance, there were some Œ some Jewish families changed their house language, their family language from Yiddish to Russian, and Lithuanians resented that, you know, he Œ he Œ they give up Yiddish, why then don™t Œ they don™t pick up Lithuanian? And Yi-Yiddish didn™t Œ didn™t bother anybody, Hebrew didn™t bother anybody, but Russian, why Russian, you know? But Œ but Œ but I heard myself, I mean, f-father and son Jewish speaking in Lithuanian. So there were those who did that, you kn ow, and w-went to Lithuanian language. Even in this museum I saw a Jewish girl writing in ghetto her d Œ her diary in Lithuanian because she Œ she ju-just didn™t know ji Œ Yiddish that well. So, there were Œ it was Œ it was a big community, it was varied situations, but generally, right or no Œ or not, but in the people there was a sense of betrayal beca use they thought that the relations were good, and they didn™t see the reason why the Jewish community is acting that way, or much of the community, in particular the younger generation. The older generation, of course, didn™t partici Œ participate in Œ in that, but as I said, they just Œ they just were in Œ behind the picture, yo u know. Nobody cared much about the Œ the Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 127rabbis or something like that, how Œ how they look at the things. Now, I also write in my memoirs that, one interesting thing that one of our Œ our family™s friend was Dr. Bridges family, Dr. Bridges, Andrew Bridges was a doctor, you know, his specialty eyes, you know, and he had some Jewish friends, some Jewish also doctors. And during the Soviet occupation, the first year of Œ the first Soviet occupation, he-he was told by one of his friends, Jewish friends, that the Jewish community leaders from the independence period, were concerned about this reaction of the younger generation, and they called some of the active Œ well, pro Œ pro-communist, younger, active people and ta lked with them, and asked them not Œ not to overdo things, that it is dangerous, that the Jewish community, living hundreds of times bet-between other nationalities, tried not to become hostile to the people they are living between. Tried to be neut ral, you know, and th -th-they e Œ taking sides, they couldn™t have survived, beca use they would also, you know, provoke a lot of hostility. And they asked those younger generation Jews to tone down, to tone down. And they said the younger Œ the you ng people just lef Œ la Œ just laughed at them. The old people they don™t understand anything, and their rules, I mean, are ob-obsolete and Œ and didn't want even to lis ten to them. So apparently even in the Jewish community, there was some perception that somebody is o-overdoing the things. Now, was Œ as I say, you know, those who were against this reaction, you know, they we Œ they were Œ they were i-in Œ invisible, they tried to be-become Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 128invisible. Now you asking about the peri od from Œ in early 1940s. Really the breakthrough was the annexation earlier, in 194 0, August, I think the third or fifth, about that time. Right after the annexation, the thing changed. Now the terror intensified consid Œ considerably, and the resistance started getting organized. So now, la Œ a lot of people, even in Œ in Œ in Œ in Œ in my class, like Grimkas(ph) and Ar-Arbuk(ph) were arrested from resistance. But even the [indecipherable] resistance, the people who were prominent in the Œ in the society generally, most of them were arrested, th-thousands now. Now it became a mass thing. Now there was nationa Œ nationalization; the business es tablishments, commercial establishments, industrial things were nationalized. I was my-myself, we Œ we s-students had to go there, write, you know, in the Œ whatever belongs to that merchant establishment, and to be nationalized with the owners. Now, somehow you know, the Lithuanian owner who owns some business or Œ or Œ or Œ or business establishment, they Œ they were just thrown out. Now the Jewish, usually you know, still remain there as a specialist. Just because usually there were some in the family, or in Œ in their circle who had influence with the new government. So apparently they tried, you know, to help each other. And pretty ba Œ became pretty obvious, you know, the things are nationalized, the Jews are still in their places, running the business as before. Of course now, in government™s name, for Œ in government™s account, Lithuanians are just without a job, you know, just Œ ju st waiting around. What™s the matter, you Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 129know, it™s always the Œ these Œ these things started accumulating. The resentment against the Jewish reaction increased strongly. As the terror increased, increased the Œ the Œ the Œ the reaction. Also, because some of them, you know, even communist Jews went into the security e-e-establishment.

segments.question: Were these people known by name, or was this just what was dis Œ this was understood, or discussed, I mean, what was th e basis of this point of view, this Œ this Œ this belief that there were Jews in the security establishment?
segments.answer: Well, they were visible.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: They went, they arrested people, they interrogated peopl e, they Œ yeah, th-th-they Œ after annexation, everything became visible. Th-They Œ they didn't Œ the terror Œ concealed terror is not a terror. I mean, they Œ and then the terror really started after the annexation. It really Œ what we suspec ted, what we were afraid, now, you know, came to fruition. Now you didn™t have to be afraid, you knew. You knew. That™s Œ that™s how it is. That™s how it is, that™s how it will be. And it Œ it Œ it gets stronger and stronger, more and more people arrested, until the big deportations.

segments.question: Well, tell us about the big deporta tions. What happened then? When did it happen, and what happened?
segments.answer: Well, it was in Œ in Œ in naja Œ I don™t remember exactly the date, but that™s 1941, June 14 maybe? About that, 14 - 13. Yeah , one night, you know, coming Œ well, in Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 130my o-op-opinion. We were walking with my father through Panevžys. There was Œ no, that was different, I™m sorry, that™s Œ that™s start of the war. Suddenly, you know, of Œ we Œ we got up one morning and saw that, you know , our friends are being Œ being taking, arrested and being taking to the railroad station. I was working in the middle of the city, and I saw, you know, a Œ a Œ a truck going there, you know, an open truck, and I saw, you kn ow, the family we knew, who was my father™s, really, superior for a time. We saw that family, the old Œ the old lady there, and their girl and him, you know, in that truck, and sold iers with the s-set bayonets around them, being taking to the railroad station. And Œ and a lot of people. Our teachers disappeared, you know. Our teacher o-of the Russian language was a Lithuanian diplomat, he was arrested, there was no Russian class there. He died from sstarvation in Siberia. And so, you know, anybody could, there was no reason, there Œ pretty soon there was no reason Œ we couldn™t detect the reason who is safe. Yeah, well, the members of the communist party, and the Œ of the communist activists, those who really contributed, who we-were working on the deportation, maybe they were safe, but nobody else. There was no, you know, anybody could be arrested, anybody could be deported.

segments.question: Did you know at that point, when you saw the truck, the open truck, that this Œ this was a Œ a deportation that was a mass deportation, or did you see many trucks go Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 131to the train station? Wa Œ can you kind of draw us a picture? What was it that you saw, and what you understood.
segments.answer: Yeah, well, I didn™t see too many be cause most of them went during the nighttime, and I don™t know why this family was picked up Œ we -well, there were more people, not only this family in the truck.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: But th-that was like after action actions, you know, something Œ people they might Œ might missed or something.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: But pretty soon we knew, I mean th-the railroad station was full of people, you know, the trains were full, and they were pushing those people, w-we Œ we knew, you know.

segments.question: Did you go to the train station?
segments.answer: No, I didn™t. I didn't. I-I didn™t want to risk be Œ because I Œ we didn™t know, w-we didn™t know Œ now we know, you know, aba Œ apparently how that was done, but at that time there was no Œ no understanding what was goi ng on and woo Œ who is in danger, who is not. My mother opened Œ and tr-tried to Œ to Œ to Œ to think what Œ what we should take to go into Siberia , you know, now. And Œ and that was open box, and she didn™t put anything in th Œ sh e just Œ just was paralyzed, you know, and that™s it, you know, we don™t Œ we don™t know. We don™t know it Œ we were sho Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 132we were shocked. We were shocked, we didn™t expect anything like that. They were saying, oh, your prostitutes are taking to Œ to Siberia, they will learn how to work. Prostitutes, the Œ the kids, the families, you know.

segments.question: Does that Ukrainian au pair still living in the house?
segments.answer: Yeah, but Œ but they were very rarely at home. Th-The ka Œ this Œ the red army was on some kind of alert already, so they we re mostly at their bases, wherever that was.

segments.question: And at that point, did you connect the dots and see what she was saying, or even then there was such confusion, that you had no idea that this could be Siberia, the Siberia she was telling you to prepare for.
segments.answer: Yeah, yeah, we connected that. We connected. And we Œ particular the Russian literature, the Soviet literature we had Œ we had to read, you know, some of the Sholokhov ™s novels, and there is about de-depor tations. And couldn™t understand, I mean, so-some Œ some silly thing, some unrealistic thing. I mean, they come, they arrest the farmers there, you know, they bring them to Siberia, but what for, I mean, what did they do, and the whole family? Why Œ why the whole family? If the farmer did something wrong, you know , hm. We di-didn™t understa nd. It Œ it looks kind of silly to me, I Œ but then I remembered, then I remembered that Œ that Œ that day.

segments.question: Okay. So Œ and then what happened? Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 133
segments.answer: Ye Œ oh Œ we didn™t know what™s going on to Œ to the extent that oh, some of the people we know, you know, when the Œ they came for them to be deported, the Œ the father of the family, the man, ran away. He saw, you know, somebody coming, he thought they™re coming to arrest him, because there were so many arrests, you know? But n-not the families, there were people arrested, whoever was, you know, they wanted to arrest. So they ran away and ha Œ hid, an d their family was taken and dep Œ brought to the railroad station. Now, the man realiz ing that, came out, went to the railroad station, and whatever happens, he wanted to be with his family. He didn™t realize that families were broken up, that the men were sent to concentration camps, and the families were sent to the Œ to the Siberian farms and something like that. So you see, even at the moment, people were so Œ that confused, didn™t know, you know, the method what wa s going on. So there was no sense for him because he was Œ he wasn™t let to go with his family.

segments.question: But he was taken?
segments.answer: He was ta Œ oh, of course, yeah, he was taken, yeah. And very few survived there, i-in there, in particular the first deportation. But, as I say, we realized that the Jews are also being deported, yes, and quite Œ quite many of them.

segments.question: How did you realize this?
segments.answer: Well, we saw, I mean, people just disappearing all Œ all ar ound you. Ma Œ my friend Rubinsteinas (ph), his family. Our Œ our classmate Borokas (ph), his family, Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 134they are deported. They were lucky. They were lucky, they didn™t know. At that time we were Œ thought it means how Œ how bad, how cruel, but they had 50 - 50 chance of survival in Siberia. My friend Rubinstein(ph) survived, and Borokas(ph) survived. They Œ they would Œ I don™t know whether Borokas(ph) was visiting Lithuania , you know, now, and Rubinstein(ph) I don™t Œ he married local girl, stayed there in Russia. Whether he visited Lithuania , I don™t know. And [indecipherable] but at that time it looked Œ the horror, the same horror as for the others. But many Jewish activists were acting in that deportation. So, again, you know, it should have been more. The Œ the people still didn™t Œ didn™t quite, you know Œ just because Jews are being deported, didn™t quite, you know, justify the whole Jewish community because of that, be cause the activists still were there, you know. Not the only ones, but there were quite a few of them, quite many. Clear majority of the civilians taking care of that, except the Russian soldiers, of course. So Œ

segments.question: So you™re saying a clear majority of those who participated in deportations happened to be Jewish?
segments.answer: I would say so, I would say so. From wh at I hear, you know, they say the Jews, the Jews, the Jews deported, you know, I don™t know. I didn't take any samples or anything like that, but from what I heard, yeah, it seemed so. Well, majority was Russian soldiers. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 135

segments.question: Yes, yes.
segments.answer: They were in each Œ in each group was one or two. Well, two, at least two, sometimes more.

segments.question: What happened then, after th is, after these deportations?
segments.answer: Well, they stopped for a Œ just few days.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: We Œ we have the feeling that it will resume, that Œ and Œ and that was right. Later we find out th-that the Œ they just Œ they just Œ system, you know, the railroads, everything, they had to make a break, and then they would have resume. So we had the feeling that they Œ it will resume, but was just a days, and the Germans attacked.

segments.question: So the war started for Lithuania then?
segments.answer: The war started for Lithuania June a Œ a Œ deportations started in June 14th, I would say, so continued about three days more, maybe Œ no, it™s three Œ well, 14, 15, 16, maybe 17, I don™t know. And 19, 20, oh yeah, and 22, June 22, the Germans attacked.

segments.question: And that™s when you last saw go Œ Uditta(ph) Gormanas (ph)?
segments.answer: Yeah, few Œ few Œ a Œ a day after that, a day after that Œ

segments.question: A day.
segments.answer: Œ I saw Uditta(ph). Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 136

segments.question: So where were you when you heard news of the German attack? Do you remember?
segments.answer: Oh, yeah, I remember. I was sleeping. I was sleeping. We Œ we graduated from our high school. There was supposed to be Œ no matter deportations, there was supposed to be a picnic in Œ in Œ in Œ in Berchunai(ph), which is a resort near Panevžys . We had to go that Œ that day, th at Sunday. And suddenly there was a thunder, a very strong thunder, and I thought, my goodness, th-there goes the picnic, you know, that is a thunderstorm. And then there was an explosion. I mean, I thought it™s thunder, but somehow the sound came through the Œ through the ground, not through the air. Such a strong that our small house, you know, just Œ just Œ

segments.question: Shook?
segments.answer: Œ swayed.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I sh Œ no Œ stood up shock a-and went out outside to see what™s going on. There was no storm, there were no clouds . The sky was clear, and pani Œ Pajuoste were Œ was the military base behind Panevžys, there was a huge cloud going up of the explosion, apparently, huge cl oud. And there were a lot of planes ou Œ in the sky, but they were high up. Now, what™s going on here, you know, something exploded in Œ in Œ in Œ in Œ in Pajuoste, definitely. So Œ and then I saw, you know, it suddenly, I think five planes came through, pretty low. Yellow s Œ this Œ the Œ the Œ the Œ yellow Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 137signs and the black crosses, black Œ oh Œ oh, I knew the German military sign Œ i-insignia. Black crosses, that was German military Œ military planes, black planes, so that was clear. Five, in formation going there, you know, on Œ over Panevžys. So that Œ that was war.

segments.question: And [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Then my mother came out, you know, and we started dancing, they are not going to defe Œ deport us to Siberia, see? War was salvation.

segments.question: For you.
segments.answer: For us, yeah, right. Yeah.

segments.question: When did you first see a German soldier?
segments.answer: There were a few days ca Œ went by, I came back from home, and we were Œ we were Œ also dur Œ during the nighttime we went outside, there was a Œ a small building, really without windows, so we thought rather a safe place, so we decided to o-over Œ stay overnight there. And we heard, you know, we heard cars going on, motorcycles, commands, but very difficult to say, commands in any language sounds similar. And suddenly a motorcycle went th rough our street very quickly. Most likely it was already the German, but we stayed inside until morning, and in the morning somebody come running and sa id, Germans are in the town.

segments.question: Was this the day after you Œ the day after the war started, or a few days Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 138
segments.answer: Oh no, no, no, Panevžys were not that fast, yeah. Vilnius, Kaunas [indecipherable] , it™s surprising Vilnius was taken first, when Œ before Kaunas, and Lithuanians rewa Œ you know, took over Vilnius even before Germans attacked. Then Kaunas the same thing. But Panevžys was between the German armored attacks. It was not that important military center, so it came Œ I think it was 26th. Warsaw the 22, the re Œ Lithuanian insurrection started 23, and Panevžys was taken, I think, 26.

segments.question: So if the insurrection started in Œ in Œ o-on June 23 rd, and you know, it was Lithuanian, how did it express itself in Panevžys, what happened there?
segments.answer: Nothing much, the Œ because nobody had weapons, organization was broken down by deportations. They was supposed to get weapons su Œ from somewhere, but the people who were supposed to get those weapons, some of them were deported, the other went into hiding. One went to Kaunas, participated the Œ in the revolt there. And Œ

segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Œ that you were taking par Œ uh-huh.
segments.answer: Yes, but Œ but nothing happened. We just didn™t have anything, no Œ no weapons, no Œ well, organization was Œ we reestablished organization, but so what?

segments.question: Yeah. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 139
segments.answer: So we Œ we just Œ

segments.question: So was it a sind Œ was it a city without any rule, or any law, or any Œ any Œ how shall I say, any government at the time?
segments.answer: No, Soviets were there, so Œ

segments.answer: Until the 26th, yeah.

segments.answer: Well, it is strange. There were moments when there were none.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: The Russians were Œ retreated, you kno w, somewhere, you know, and there was none. And then the Russia ns again, came again.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: There was a moment when there was a rumor that Germans ar e in the city, and the NKVD took off.

segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 140
segments.answer: Th-They took off and Œ and the rest of the Russians took off, and there was the city without an-any government. And then th ey realized that it™s not true, so they came back.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: There was terror, you know, they were Œ they were murdering Œ murdering people at the factory, sugar factory, tens Œ tens of people, and there were those doctors, surgeons, three surgeons and the nurse which were very cruelly murdered. Well, the terror was Œ in Œ in Œ in Panevžys .

segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.answer: Well, for Œ from Œ from the telling, you know, from Œ

segments.answer: Œ from Œ from the people, yes.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: But that Œ that was factual information, as we found out. It wasn™t a Œ a rumor. Yeah, so Œ

segments.question: Did you stay at home during these days that Œ
segments.answer: No, no, w-we decided t Œ we didn't find any we-weapons , we didn™t do anything useful, so my friend and myself decided to go to a neighboring vil-village behind the Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 141city, and Œ to see may the Œ maybe there the −auliai have hidden some weapons, maybe so. So we went there, didn™t find anything. Yeah, ba Œ the Soviet m-mili Œ Soviet mi-military came upon, you know, and were ch Œ starting shooting at us, so we ran away and hid. And we sit Œ sit ther e for two or three days, and then I decided to come back to Panevžys , and I came back and the city was kind of dead. In Œ in the early afternoon there were nobody watchi ng the streets except the military patrol Œ patrols.

segments.question: And this was Soviet still military?
segments.answer: Soviet, Soviet, yeah, so Œ so when I Œ when I saw them or heard them, I just made a Œ a turnaround through other streets, you know, and came home, finally without Œ without meeting any of them directly, face to face. Meanwhile, the prison was evacuated and many of the people were being killed at the sugar factory. But if Œ

segments.question: Why were they being killed at the sugar Œ sugar factory is just a place where Œ where candy was manufactured, or sugar was Œ
segments.answer: No, sugar, sugar, sugar.

segments.question: Œ sugar was manufactured?
segments.answer: Well, it was just apparently convenient pl ace, I don™t know, they just dig the Œ the ditches and kill the people. They were mostly from Œ from other towns brought to Panevžys. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 142

segments.question: So it was used as a quasi prison or a holding place and Œ and a Œ and then became an execution site?
segments.answer: Yes, I Œ I would say so, yes.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: But th-then the prison became empty and some of the prisoner Œ pr Œ people who worked in the prison [indecipherable] my mother. My father was digging di Œ digging anti Œ anti-aircraft, you know, we ll ditches, how do you call, you know?

segments.question: Trenches?
segments.answer: Trenches, yes. So he was not home, I was not home, my mother was home. So he Œ she Œ she thought that I might be a rrested there, and they arrested. The NKVD arrested a lot of young people in the streets, including my friends.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: So my fr Œ wh-wh-when my mother knew that, you know, the Œ was told that the NKVD, the Soviet secret police left the prison, she told other people in the neighborhood that, let™s go there and Œ an d let people out, you know, from the prison. So one of the neighbors brought a ladder, came over, you know, opened the Œ the gate, and went to the prison. Some of the prisoners were already breaking out from their cells, but it was very slow thing, so he showed where the keys are, and opened all the keys, and sudde nly prison was empty. All th is young people came out into the neighboring houses, and meanwhile NKVD came back. They Œ they had Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 143somebody guarding, and gave a signal that they are coming back, so everybody disappeared and they came back to the empty Œ empty pris on. Well, was too late to do anything, it was hours before the Germ ans appeared. But still, you know, the Œ the Œ they Œ they knocked out a German Œ a Œ a Soviet tank somewhere you know, I don™t know, he was late, some [indecipherable] . So that™s Œ that™s how Œ how it was.

segments.question: Now, in many places, pogroms starte d even before the Germans came.
segments.answer: Right, yes.

segments.question: Did that happen in Panevžys as far as you know?
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: No, I Œ it™s a Œ my Œ what I know, what I have seen, is limited.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: I realize that, you know, [indecipherable] from what I read, was completely different in Kaunas. The Germans came in right there and started anti-Jewish actions right there involving Lithuanians. In Vilnius also pretty soon like that. But Panevžys the Germans didn™t care about anything except their military tasks, whatever they had. And nobody attacked Jews until Œ until the funeral of the doctors and the other people who were killed by the Soviets. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 144

segments.question: Tell us about how they were killed, the doctors, and then what was this funeral, when was it, and why was this a catalyst?
segments.answer: Why the doctors were killed is Œ is Œ I Œ ou Œ nobody really understands.

segments.question: What were the circumstances of Œ
segments.answer: The doctors were operating on Soviet soldiers which were injured by the German bombing of Pajuoste . They were brought to the hospital and the doctors, the surgeons were working on them, operating, and the nurse also, she Œ she works wi-with the doctors. Now, somebody said that somebody broken into the hospital looking for weapons, because the soldiers brought to the hospital, they thought maybe they could get weapons there. Whic h is nonsense, nobody brought them with the be Œ weapons. I mean, they were injured Œ injured soldiers, so they were brought to the hospital, the weapons stayed wherever they were serving. But I don™t know how much is rumor, how much is right, but in any case, there were some communist youth guards in the hospital and they telephoned the security that somebody is trying to break into the hospital.

segments.question: That is the secret police, the Soviet Œ
segments.answer: Secret police, yeah. And then the secret police came, took the doctors, took the nurse and just Œ just killed them Œ not Œ no t just shot, but really, you know, murder Œ murdered them to Œ to death, you know, by Œ by Œ by horrible, horrible torture. How? It™s Œ it™s nonsense, I mean, th e doctors, I d Œ I don™t know why. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 145

segments.question: And you found out about thi Œ
segments.answer: I-It would Œ you see, the people Œ the people are most dangerous, and most cruel when they are very afraid. Russians were, at that time, they were afraid. They were su-suddenly confronted with the German ac tion, which was very powerful, and they were afraid, they Œ they Œ they realized that all the surroundings are hostile to them, the Lithuanian surroundings, so they were terrified. And terrified people are dangerous people, because they are irrational then, and they just Œ so-so that Œ that™s Œ that™s my observation from that. So I Œ that™s how I can explain that, because there is Œ does Œ doesn™t make any sense, there we re n-no weapons in the Œ in the hospital and no possibility of the weapons [indecipherable] real, you know. So so-somebo Œ somebody got scared, c onfused, you know.

segments.question: And so Œ and they did away with them.
segments.answer: Oh, of course, yeah, then the funeral, bu-but not only the doctors, but also the people, about I don™t know, 20 - 30 people at the Œ at this sugar factory, various people who were arrested by securities earlier. There, you know, in command, was that Lithuanian communist who was living in our house. He was in command of that execution.

segments.question: Ahh. Ah.
segments.answer: And th-there Œ there was different, there they Œ they were executing because they thought, I mean, this is anti-Soviet people. Ma Œ so then th Œ not Œ not in such a fear Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 146and as Œ as in the case of the doctors. Now, nobody until now, I never heard that anybody would men Œ mention that any Jew was involved in that. We don™t know Russian security personnel, maybe there were, maybe there were not, but nobody established that any Jew ba Œ that Lithuani an was is Œ in command, you know, at the sugar factory that wo Œ

segments.question: So, another betrayal of a Œ of the wors t kind, is a Œ it is a Lithuanian who is a communist Œ
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Œ who is killing his own people?
segments.answer: That™s right.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: That™s right. Yeah, so Œ so there was no Œ no reason for any anti-Jewish action, but there was. After the funeral, I went [indecipherable] they said they are beating Jews. Well, I went to see wha Œ where, you know, and really we saw it, you know, the people were just standing and watching . And three, maybe four, most likely three burly men were hitting, you know, at the small houses there Œ there were Jewish sstores, you know, several Jewish stores at that place. They were just breaking the windows, the doors, you know, beating it up. And the people were just standing and watching what™s going on. Nobody said, you know, anything to them, to those three peop-people there. Obviously they were a Œ a Œ there were Jews there, you know, Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 147living in there. And suddenly a man came out with a bl-bloody face, apparently a Jew. And when the people saw the blood, y ou know, all this group of people who were standing yo Œ just stepped back, y ou know, maybe three steps back and disdispersed right there. They were calling, you know, to join the people, but nobody joined them.

segments.question: The three burly men were calling to Œ
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Œ have people join them.
segments.answer: Yeah, but we Œ nobody joined, but no-nobody even objected to anything.

segments.question: Okay, so nobody condemned, either.
segments.answer: No. Well, I think it was implied, condemnation. It was implied. People Œ people, but Œ

segments.question: But they didn™t say anything.
segments.answer: They didn™t say Œ they say Œ didn™t say anything, yeah. And they just dispersed, and Œ obviously they were sent from some where, you know. Obviously some Œ some [indecipherable] tha-that was not s Œ anything spontaneous. But Œ

segments.question: And do you think there was a connecti on between the funeral of these Œ you know, these people who were victims of the NKVD and that Lithuanian communist and whatever you know, units or rule that he had? Do y Œ do you think it was just coincidence that it happened this way?

So apparently somebody want to make a connection, sent those three men there, you know, maybe paid them, and tried to Œ

segments.answer: Œ in-insight them. I don™t know. Not as Œ as far as me is concerned, but I don™t know about the other people. I don™t thin k so. I don™t think that even after that, nobody Œ nobody talked ab-about the Jews in connection with that Œ with those br Œ

segments.question: Incidents. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 149
segments.answer: Œ those incidents, yeah. So Œ

segments.answer: Okay.

segments.question: And you Œ you Œ you first saw the planes and so on. When it finally was established, that is, there was no return of any Soviet forces, is that when the funeral took place? Was it at that point Œ
segments.answer: Oh no, several days after that.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Several days after that, I don™t know how many Œ you know, two or Œ two Œ at least two, maybe three days after that, because the Germans had time to bring foreign journalists from Berlin by plane, they brought to Panevžys to show the journalists what the Russians have done.

segments.question: Mm-hm.

And I know about that story because there was one Lithuanian from Klaipdos, Klaip da Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 150area. He was very much anti-German, his whole life anti-German, but he knew languages, and he Œ he was a refugee when the Germans took over Klaipda, he lived in Panevžys. But he was kind of drafted, or asked as a translator for the journalists. Journalists knew German, but not the real Lithuanian kn-knew German good enough.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And he knew. So, the Germans brought them to those doctors and others and showed the places, and then later there was kind of like, I don™t know, like place for Œ for them to wait until the plane was ready to take them back. And this Lithuanian translator whom I Œ who Œ was also our fam ily friend, so he was telling us that one of the American journalists took him away and said, look, you know, this, all those killed people, that™s Œ that™s what the Germans did, didn™t they? He said no, no, no, that Œ that was Soviets. Oh, he says, that™s Œ that™s clear, that™s clear, thank you. And then he wanted to Œ to Œ to talk with him and the American wouldn™t talk with him at all. So the German propaganda didn™t take, I mean, the Œ the Œ that Œ at least this journalist was convinced that was a German Œ

segments.question: Action.
segments.answer: Œ action. And this, from Œ from Klaipda, who all his life was fighting against the Germans, and e-even until Œ he always was, even after that inc Œ incident, but Œ but he was upset about the Œ th-the western prejudices. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 151

segments.question: And he Œ th Œ it sounds like the wester n journalist, the American journalist, was looking upon him, the translator as being in the service of the Germans, because it served the German propaganda privasses.
segments.answer: Right, right. Well, apparently he was convinced that the Russians don™t do such things, nome Œ and the Germans do. Which is true as Œ as far as the Germans are concerned, just the first Œ just the first part not Œ not true.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah. So let™s go forward.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: And the funeral happens, you see the Œ this beating up of Œ of Jews and their houses by these three men. And then what happens within Panevžys ? How do things develop further?
segments.answer: Well, horribly, because there were a lot of killing. Revenge killing.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: People, you know, ju-just under suspicion that somebody was in the communist youth organization or someth ing, were taken out and shot, without any i-inquiry, without any court, without any pro-procedur e, just like that, you know, and a lot of innocent people were just killed, like this Œ in Panevžys and in surrounding villages, like that. It was terrible. Some of them were Jewish, I don™t know how many of those, but definitely just some Œ some Jews were killed. Some Lithuanians, some Russians, whatever. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 152

segments.question: Do y Œ was this done Œ was this done without German involvement? Was this sort of like a [indecipherable]
segments.answer: I would say without.

segments.question: Without.
segments.answer: Ja Œ that was just Lithuanian project.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Not Œ not a project, there was a staff, you know, just when the Germans marched Œ marched in, I saw the Germans right there, you know, at my gymnasium, and the girls were, you know, greeti ng them with flowers and Œ and milk and water and [indecipherable] you know [indecipherable] and one of our classmates who ran away to Germany was Œ I didn™t see him, but he went by, you know, he was drafted by Germans as translator, going through Lithuania. So we Œ Lithuanian flags everywhere. The only German flag under their military establishment, and even that flag was a war flag, not the regular German flag.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: So, according to that, that™s kind of correct, I mean, that™s the army. They don™t claim that Œ that city or that part. So Œ and there was a staff, Lithuanian staff is Œ they said, I went there, you know, and so Œ volunteered for in Œ ins Œ in service there. They gave me a Œ a rifle, the automatic Russian Œ automatic rifle, ammunition, and a Œ a Œ how do you call it, armband. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 153

segments.question: Mm-hm. What color is it?
segments.answer: It Œ it identify Œ pardon me?

segments.question: What color was it?
segments.answer: It was red.

segments.question: It was red?
segments.answer: What was surprising, but there were signs, you know, ah-ah-ah-ah Œ was ga Œ was a red Œ up in the red material or something. In Panevžys it was red, but it was Œ it had insignias, it Œ different insignia. And that™s it, we went into th Œ into the service there.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Apparently some from our service were killing people, apparently. I don™t know, after that, whe-when they were killing, apparently they felt like big heroes, you know. Like Œ

segments.question: Killing anti-com Œ killing communists, killing Jews?
segments.answer: Yeah, killing communists.

segments.question: Killing communists.
segments.answer: Communists. J-Jews weren™t Œ at that point wer Œ I don™t think Œ I am not sure, but I don™t think they were killed just because they were Jews. They suspected they are communists, that™s Œ something lik e that. Anyway, not the families Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 154

segments.question: And were these people who Œ who were, you know, when you volunteered, and others, were they all about your age, about 18 - 19 at the time, or Œ
segments.answer: They were sa Œ yes, well, the lower, ba Œ ba Œ could be Œ could be higher than that, too. In their 20s something, up to 26 - 27 maybe. Something like that. So, pretty soon, you know, the people in Œ in Panevžys were very concerned about that, that innocent people are being killed, so they had contacted the leadership of that staff, and you know, said Œ and then, you know, the Œ the staff Œ staff was responsible, they get weapons. Th-Th-They have those armbands. So after that they stopped this thing.

segments.question: What did they a Œ what had been your duties? You we ren™t involved in that, but what had they asked you to do?
segments.answer: Well, my first duty, or first thing, we Œ they Œ they send me to Pajuoste together with others in Œ in Œ in a truck, to pi ck up the ammunition. There was a lot of ammunition, loose ammunition in Pajuoste. So, we went there and took the Œ those heavy boxes of ammunition in the tr uck, and brought to the staff.

segments.question: And is that when you had last seen Uditta(ph) Gormanas (ph), at that point, or at Œ
segments.answer: No, no, that before, that™s Œ

segments.question: That was already before.
segments.answer: Th-That was before. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 155

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And Œ okay, then Œ then we se Œ wait, we went back, second time. Second time when we back, Germans Œ Germ an soldiers were there, they just looked. Wh-What are you doing, you know, here? We s Œ we said we have, you know, the instructions from our staff to take ammunition. Out. Out of here, no ammunition, nothing. Well, out, okay. So we went back to staff, said to them, and Germans didn™t let us pick up any more. Okay. So then tol Œ they told me to take a group of my friends and go and see the Œ there is a report that some communists, or maybe even Russian soldiers, straggling soldiers are in a big building, Meistas(ph) factory, or a Œ a b Œ a building, that they might be hiding there.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Check that. Okay, I go with my f Œ my Œ my men in there, you know, to check that, and well, the building is high, hm. There are very few windows, only very high up. Well, we started approaching the build ing, everybody just coming together, I said no, I mean, if they was going to shoot, you know, they got us all, so just spread, just spread. And we approaching the building and then the German comes in, the German sergeant and asks, who is in charge of this thing? They Œ so Œ so me, you know? He co Œ approached me and said, hey, what™s going on, what Œ what war are you fighting here? Well, what war? Well, I patiently explained to him that I have instructions, something [indecipherable] report there about something like that. Out. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 156I Œ I am taking over this duty, I will take care of that. So, we wanted to stay and take a look, you know, how Œ

segments.question: How he takes care of it.
segments.answer: Œ how he takes care of it. No, he didn™t let us, you know. He just chased us away. Well, going to staff, reporting another, you know, no Œ no success there. Okay, so another reports. Some communists may be in some other building. Okay, we go to another building. Well, it™s a small, small house, small wooden Œ not a shack really, a house, but it™s a small one Œ one Œ one st ore building. Well, the report is that the communists are th Œ a-are there, you know, or Œ or the activists there. Looking, no nothing Œ nothing happening in there. So he said well, somebody, a volunteer is going inside to see what™s going on. No vo lunteers. No volunteers , well, what do we do? You Œ you can™t wait until the night, so I™m suppose Œ then I™m going there. Okay, go inside, kick in the door, you know, the door not locked, opens. I thought maybe somebody will throw grenade or Œ or Œ or shoot, but there was nobody inside, empty. But there was something, the [indecipherable] was not quite, some Œ somebody Œ there was food, there were things, somebody left it in very big haste.

segments.question: Hurried manner, yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah, definitely there was something, but at that time there were nothing, empty. Okay, I™ll come back, report that, nothing there. So they send me, alone now, report that a Œ a Jewish communist killed himself, shot himself. Go there and see what™s Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 157what Œ about that report. Okay, I go there, in the center of the city, and go, a famil Œ an old people, fam Œ family living there, a very nice, old man and old woman living in a small apartment, very nice, very tidy. Very scared people. I asked about that, yes, there is somebody died, y ou know, in Œ in Œ in the Œ in a shed outside. Outs Œ so I went into the shed, yes, there is a man, you know, who apparently killed himself, because his pistol was right there, you know, and a lot of money, Russian, Soviet money. And a s Œ a small piece of paper, you know, with scribbled writing, but not Lithuanian, apparently Yiddis h. So I looked at, he Œ he was dead, definitely. I took the pistol, and the money.

segments.question: Was he shot in the head? Did he shoot himself Œ
segments.answer: In the head. Yeah, he shot himself in the head.

segments.question: Was this the first time you saw a corpse? Because up until here, we haven™t talked about you Œ you™ve talked about things you heard.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: But not necessarily wh at you yourself saw.
segments.answer: No, I Œ the only corpses I have seen before, and a f Œ few of them were during the funerals, during the wake. But also very few of them. But Œ

segments.question: So this one is the first sort of war Œ result of Œ casualty of war.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Casualty of Œ of Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 158
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Œ these events.
segments.answer: Right. But at that time, you know, ther e was so many dangers we went through, that it didn™t affect me very much. I took it as a fact, was just the man killed himself. I Œ I have a task here now, to Œ

segments.question: What did he look like? Do you remember?
segments.answer: Y-Young man, not gray, dark hair. I woul d say in Œ in his 30s, maybe. Okay, so I take his weapon, his Œ his pistol, his Œ his Œ my Œ the money, and the Œ the s Œ the note and went back to the old Jewish couple , and asked them to tr anslate for me this Œ this note. They did, I scribbled out the translation, and he said that, you know, I am Œ he is Œ he always was a communist, be lieved in communism and now he™s dying for the communist [indecipherable] and something like long live Stalin, or something like that. Okay, I wrote it down, and thanked the Œ the people, and said, you know, report to your commu nity to f Œ to get the funeral of him, bury him. The people were so co Œ you know, they were also so scared, you know, saying [indecipherable]

segments.question: [indecipherable] yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah, what will happen with us, what will happen w ith us? I said, well nothing, old people, you know, what could happen to them? But Œ nothing, you know, don™t Œ don™t worry, you know. Oh Œ and the Germ ans are marching, you know, through the Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 159windows you can see artillery going, you know, all Œ all the German Œ German thing. Well, what the Œ I Œ I really believed Œ I really believed that they are in no danger whatsoever, just like Uditta(ph). Was Œ I believed it was in no danger, I believed that these old people are in no danger whatsoever. So Œ
