segments.question: This is a continuation of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Algimantas Gureckas , on October 14th, 2010. So, Mr. Gureckas, you were with this old Œ this old couple who were very frightened, old Jewish couple.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: And you had just found the corpse of a young man in their shed. Do you think there was a connection between this young man and them?
segments.answer: I think so. I think h-he might have been th -their son, or Œ or a close relative, but I Œ I didn™t enquire that, and I thought, you know Œ

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Œ I Œ I Œ I Œ I ch Œ I shouldn™t. I mean, we were Œ we just Œ just Œ maybe not, I don™t know.

segments.question: So that was your fourth Œ that was your fourth Œ
segments.answer: Task.

segments.question: Œ task. And you returned to your headquarters?
segments.answer: My headquarters, gave the pistol, the am-ammunition, gave the money, gave the note and the translation, and that was a da y™s work done. So went back home with my friends, and my father met us with the Œ a toast for a free and independent Lithuania , which we thought it™s being established now, because all the city was Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 161just in Lithuanian national colors, and the flags, except for one building where the German commandant was Œ took ove r the place. So Œ so tha Œ at that pla Œ what we thought is going Œ going to happen, there will be, well maybe not quite independent, but something like Hungary, or Œ or Slovakia, something like that, you know, that we will Œ will be independent country together with Œ with Germany, you know, allied willingly or not. And then the other day, I went to the police, I don™t know why, do-don™t remember exactly, went to the police, and Œ but I remember the view, which was very shocking to me. There was an old man, apparently a Jew, an old man, you know, and he was standing like in the corner, and on his forehead was written in, I would say maybe it looked lik e wet ashes, you know, make something like that and then smear on that, and it was called žydas.

segments.question: In Lithuanian.
segments.answer: In Lithuanian.

segments.question: So that means Jew.
segments.answer: Jew.

segments.question: And he was inside the police station?
segments.answer: And he was inside the police station, was standing in the corner, the people were going around their business there, you know, nobody was paying any attention to him as far as I could see. I don™t know, I Œ I ju st left that police and j-just stays in my Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 162memory, you know, bec-because it was such a shocking, shocking view for me, for me.

segments.question: Was he Œ do Œ was he Œ you say he was an old man, do you remember what he looked like? Was he small, was he large?
segments.answer: No, he was small, he was bald, yeah. That Œ that Œ that was very shocking to me, that™s why I remember it. Well, I went back home, then didn™t ha ve any di Œ nothing when I went to staff, they had nothing for me for awhile. We met some Germans, we drank with them. My school German became conversational, but my Œ when we are Œ get drunk, you don™t have inhibitions, so it™ s mech Œ much earlier Œ easier to learn. The Germans were very friendly, the soldiers. They were Œ they were soldiers, that™s all they c-cared, you know, they wer Œ they were fighting their Œ the war, and no politics, nothing her-here. They were friendly people. Now, another day I went, and they had another task to me. And the Ru ssians Œ the railroad was a regular western European railroad in Lithuania, the width. The Russian railroads had different width. So when the Russians took over, they made a more wide, you know, on the Œ

segments.question: Mm-hm, a wider [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Œ the Russian Œ a Russian standard. Now, the Germans wanted us to bring it back to the west European, German, or previous Lithuanian st andard. So I had to Œ to Œ to go to the prison. There was prisoners of war, Russians, Soviets, you know, Ukrainians, whatever. I had to take 120 - 150 of them and bring to the railroad, and Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 163let them work on the railroad bringing the Œ the Œ the rail width to the regular side. And, to watch what Œ with my friends al so, to watch them, you know, working there. So that™s what we did.

segments.question: So you guarded them, in other words.
segments.answer: We guarded them, yeah.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: And they were Œ they were working there. It was easy Œ well, of course, not very easy, easy because th-there were, you know, before, that width, so it was just re-return to the old place. And it was narrower, so it™s no problem, n-no Œ no Œ no need to extend anything or someth ing. But, you know, the rails are heavy, you have to Œ to lift them and bring it, and so Œ so it was w-work, you know [indecipherable] many of them. Now, I was the control. The Ukrainians were very happy people there. They were, you know, full of fun, you know, they Œ they had all kinds of funny stories, and I s-started, you know, to talk with them.

segments.question: In Russian?
segments.answer: In Russian, yeah. They said, you know, all Œ they were all happy. They knew the war was over, will be over in months, they go back to free Ukraine, everything will be just fine. And I saw that I lost, I mean , you know, a war discipline, they Œ they are not working, they are just entertaining me. So, I had problem, you know, until I [indecipherable] on them to work. The Russians were very up Œ not very, but they Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 164are upset, sad, you know. They were working, but obviously they Œ they Œ they were not happy, not like Ukrainians, it™s Œ it™s a very big difference between. There were other nationalities. There was one of them, they knew no Russian.

segments.question: But it was a Soviet soldier?
segments.answer: It was a Soviet soldier, he was from Kaukas (ph) or somewhere, th-the Russians told me, he is from Kaukas(ph), so he doesn™t know a ny Russian. Yeah, so I don™t know who he was, but di Œ you showed to him, he-he did, you know, whatever. They never Œ I wa Œ I never asked them, but th ey never complained, th-they Œ I never asked how they are fed or something like th at, but apparently there were no problem, because nobody complained to me that they didn't have hot food or anything.

segments.question: How did they look?
segments.answer: They look alright to me. There is just a few days Œ

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Œ they became p-prisoners of war. They were under Lithuanians, not under the German rule. The Germans some Œ somehow, you know, they are supposed to be under the Germans, you know, but they were under the Lithuanians. So they working several days, we were working at that™s Œ that™s rail Œ rail somehow is re-established the Œ the discipline with Œ with a difficulty with my Ukrainian friends. And finally, it was going fr Œ really fast, you know, the Œ the work was done, some distance from Panevžys , and that was done, you know, my task was finished, I Œ back to the staff, Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 165gave back the rifle, the ammunition, the armband, was done. Went home. My participation in the second World War was complete, without the Œ

segments.question: At that point.
segments.answer: Yeah, without point. Let me tell you, at that point Œ withou t Œ without Œ without any shot being fired from my gun, I Œ I didn't Œ didn™t have any Œ no need, no opportunity. I wasn™t in any fi-fighting in the action, nothing. So I came back home and just was waiting until the Lithuanian army will be reestablished, we will be mobilized and we™ll be sent to fight the Œ th e Soviets together with the Germans, just like Finns, like Hungarians, Italians, Bulgarians are doing. So that was the big illusion, you know, and no Œ no Germans didn™t Œ didn™t want any Œ any of our services, and Œ of Lithuania™s service. Now, as far as the Jews are concerned, until that, you know, nothing happ ened except for those p-previ Œ early executions. The early executions, of some of the com Œ my communist friends, you know, that Œ who were in the communist youth organization, fl ed together with the Soviet army when the Germans approached Panevžys.

segments.question: So you had communi Œ you had fri ends who had been part of the [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Yeah, they were from my class, well, what can you do? So, yeah, th-the two of them were killed, you know, there in action, you know, against the German. They tried to attack a German tank, and they were killed. But the others retreated together Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 166with the Œ some communists w ith the si Œ this communist who lived in our house and who was participating in executions at the Œ

segments.question: Sugar shack.
segments.answer: Œ sugar factory. And th-those come Œ those communist youth people, they Œ they got rifles, they were Œ had weapons, and they were f-fleeing together with the red army, retreating. The Germans, well, you need map really. The Germans went one way from K-Kaunas to Dofilis(ph) in Latvia, Pskov in Russia, directly towards Saint Peterburg; Leningrad , at that time.

segments.question: Mm-hm, exactly.
segments.answer: But one f Œ another was big Œ big move from Pilzzeit (ph) to Taurag , −iauliai , [indecipherable] Riga, and farther away into Estonia. And Panevžys is in between. So they were fleeing toward north, not toward the east. Of course, toward the east the Germans were already advancing there. They fled to Œ reached Latvia , Jkabpils, which is on the Daugava river. And so that on the other side of Daugava are Œ the German tanks are going. Appare ntly Œ the communists apparently, for instance, this communist who lived in our house, de Œ he survived. He Œ he e Œ he escaped.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: He escaped, because he later was parachuted into Lithuania , caught by the Germans and Œ and hanged by the Germans. And so he Œ he escaped, but then of Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 167course was thrown back as a paratrooper. But my f Œ but the young friends from the communist youth thought it™s Œ it™s hopeless. They said that they threw their rifles into the Daugava river, and walked back to Panevžys . Well, it took couple of weeks, I guess, until they arrived back. Nobody was interested, nobody bothered them, nobody enquired about them, nothing. If they wouldn™t have fled, they would have shot. They would have killed.

segments.question: They would have been killed.
segments.answer: The first Œ first day, yeah. Such people like them, they were killed first day, no questions asked. What a difference two w eeks made. Nobody was interested, nobody even asked them where they were.

segments.question: Or who they were.
segments.answer: Or who they were, yeah. They lived just normal life. One of them™s living in Klaipda now, raising his family, that™s Œ he was Russian, yeah, ethnic Russian. Yeah, so.

segments.question: So, you Œ you fired not a single shot from your rifle?
segments.answer: Not a single shot.

segments.question: But you said that some who di d join this national guard, the −auliai , you had heard that they had been implicated in murders Œ
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Œ and in massacres. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 168
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: What is it that you heard, and did you know of these people personally?
segments.answer: Well, there™s the problem. I think when they were killing the people, they thought they doing some kind of a heraic Œ heroic work. But they very quickly found out that everybody looks very, you know, agains Œ ev-everybody™s we Œ very much against that, and they condemned such a t Œ such a action. So they didn™t brag about that any more, and so I just heard the rumors, yeah, from my class, about one, yes, but it™s a rumor, he never talked about anyt hing like that, so I Œ I don™t know. I can™t accuse him, because this is terrible accusation, and well, he is killed. H-He is killed by the Œ by the s Œ by the Soviets, but Œ on second occupation, he Œ they found his remains in ter Œ what does Œ near Vilnius there, the burial place. But Œ but I don™t know. Just a rumor about him.

segments.question: But when we™re talking about massacres, are we talking about massacres of Jews, or are we talking about revenge shooting of communists, some of whom might be Jewish, some of whom would not be?
segments.answer: I imagine that it™s Œ it™s killing of the communists.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Yeah. Jews and not Jews. Definitely not Jews, because we know, I mean, who are killed. As far as Jews are concerned, we didn™t have that many people so we identify, you know, how many and where. I sa Œ would suspect that the Jews had the worst Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 169chance to survive in the Œ th an the Lithuanian communists. Well, Lithua Œ be Œ if they decided to kill, I mean, there was no chance any more. You know, they decide, this is a communist, let™s shoot him. And th ey shot Œ shot him. But I think they had stupid errors, you know, of killing people who were not communi sts, could happen for the Jews much easier, because Œ

segments.question: Of the suspicion?
segments.answer: Sus-Suspicion and not knowing the comm unity that well. In Lithuanian case pretty much well Œ was known who was, yo u know, wa Œ involved that much. So I suspect that maybe more Jews. But anyway, they were not killed, there were not mass executions like later. There were not executions of children, women. Well, women, unless they themselves were implicated, but Œ but not like, you know, the whole families or something like that. Just Œ just thought he™s a communist, a Jew a communist, we™ll kill him, kill him. That™s my impression. I Œ I wasn™t close to those things, I saw Œ well, it™s difficult to say, but it was definitely not Œ not a mass ex Œ extermination of the Jews Œ

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Œ at that point, yet.

segments.question: At what point did that start? Let™s go Œ let™s go to this point [indecipherable] Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 170
segments.answer: Oh yeah, well, that™s another story. Sin ce Œ you know, it became a pr Œ as far as I was concerned, became a quiet time, you know, no Œ no Œ no service in the Œ in the mi Œ of military or police or anyt hing like that, I th rough with that.

segments.question: You™re finished with high school.
segments.answer: You™re finished with high school. So my friend from my Œ from my s Œ class, asked me to come to the village to be a guest in his sister™s Œ sister™s ba Œ wedding. And so we went, I went with Œ to my Œ near Œ near Biržai , his Œ his village, and there was a very si Œ big wedding, you know, a lot of Biržai beer, which is very good, very, you know, homemade. Fine, so we celebrated there. Now, after that, he decided to show me the Biržai and the Œ and the area around, area where he was born and grown and he wanted to show me. Well we went to Biržai, went, met the girls there, was nice. And the last day before I-I came home, we were walking through his village. There were no buildings around, there were fields and roads, and there came a man on a bicycle. And this man came to a Œ both of us and said, do you know? Biržai Jews are Œ have been killed. We were shocked, I mean, wha-what Œ what do you mean? He didn™t say hello or anything like that, that was the first words he said, do you know?

segments.question: A total stranger, yes.
segments.answer: Total stranger. Do you know the Biržai Jews were killed? No. We were Œ we were shocked. And he started telling, he Œ he just had to tell that the German Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 171commandant, the German military said Œ the Jews were in the ghetto already. He said that they found, the Germans found that the Jews had hidden weapons, and because of that, you know, he t Œ took all the Jews, and brought to someplace, you know, outside the city, and they just killed all the Jews. All, he said. Children, babies. The German officer was walking ar ound and shooting babies in the mothers™ hands. Whether he participated or not, I don ™t know, but he was shocked. At least he was apparently guarding, or so. He was Œ he Œ eyewitness. No question about that.

segments.question: What would have made you think that he might have participated in it, or in Œ been involved in some way?
segments.answer: I don™t know.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I don™t know. I Œ

segments.question: But he was an eyewitness, at any rate.
segments.answer: He Œ well, yeah, he was telling with details everything what was going on. He was telling about the doctor who was not brou ght to the Œ he was so m Œ valued that they didn™t bring him to the Œ the ghetto, he still stayed at his home and his office. And the Germans came to pick him up and bring with the other Jews, and he said no, he is not going anywhere. And the Œ well, the German officer pulled out the pistol and just shot him right there in his office. And thi-this is Œ they said, I mean, they just put him in Œ in the truck and brought to the execution place and threw in with Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 172the others. And he Œ he described the execution in great detail. He said, the ra Œ re Œ Germans were killing, Lithuanians were k illing also there, the Œ those Jews, you know, and he Œ he told him particularly he Œ the ch Œ the killing of the babies for him you Œ was Œ was Œ was the thing, I mean, he just couldn™t Œ he said, after that, I mean, he Œ he just resigned from Œ from the se rvice, and he doesn™t want even to see.

segments.question: Was he a policeman?
segments.answer: Well, like auxiliary policeman at that time, not a regular in uniform or anything like that, no. Tho-Those are Œ were not invol ved in Œ in Œ in usually in Œ in Jews™ execution. But that was Œ we were shocked also, hearing that. And we thought that™s Œ it™s a unique thing, as I read in Napoleon™s biography right before going there, you know. Th Œ having time I just picked up a book and read Napoleon™s biography. And there is an incident where Napoleon killed the prisoners of war in Œ in Akah(ph), in Œ in Œ today Israel, at that time Turkish Palestine. And even, I thought, I mean, even Œ even Napoleon, whe Œ really a reasonable military leader, he did things, and I thought well, Biržai will be also in history like Jaffa, you know, some cruelty which happens during th e war, you know, without any reason, something Œ well, what do you mean, I m ean Jews were hiding weapons. Maybe they were hiding weapons, but somebody prep ared even the ditches for the Œ for the Œ for th Œ for them to be killed, you know, before that. So s Œ must be just Œ just a pretense. So, we Œ we thought that something what™s ha Œ what™s happened in Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 173Biržai , the Œ we Œ I went back to Panevžys , you know, and then I found out no, this thing is going all around. And th en we found out not only in Lithuania but in Latvia also. Hm. Now Œ then we [indecipherable] we saw, in our gymnasium, in ou-our high school came a German detachme nt, not the regular military, I don™t know, the uniforms were somewhat different, they have digging equipment a lot, and there was Œ they will kill Panev žys Jews also, the rumor was there. And of course we believed because we knew what happened in Biržai . It was terrible. By the way, I bir Œ didn™t mention how the ge Œ ghetto was established, fairly early, but not the first day, not e Œ not even the first week. The Germans had all kinds of announcements, and telling what to do, retu rn the weapons, this, that, you know, all kinds of things, and u-underneath it was Œ my friends said, you know, if Œ if it™s not written [indecipherable], we™ll Œ we™ll executed Œ them Œ it™s Œ

segments.question: We™ll be shot.
segments.answer: Œ yeah, we™ll shot. Not Œ not worth even re ading, but if it says we™ll shot, at least I read it. But there was another announ cement with Œ not in German format, establishing a ghetto in Panevžys, and requiring to wear this yellow star. Not to walk on the sidewalks, all this thing. I cannot remember, I™m sorry I can™t remember who signed that, whether it was a Lithuanian mayor, or was a German officer, I cannot remember who Œ who is Œ un-under whose authority was written Œ although I Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 174know that in some cases Germans printed, a mayor who didn™t sign. [indecipherable]

segments.question: It doesn™t matter.
segments.answer: But doesn™t matter, but I don™t know in Panevžys , under whose authority it was announced. And the ghetto was established. At the beginning, the idea of ghetto didn™t seem such terrible, because we thought about medieval ghettos. Jews living separately, but well, we imagined, you know, we knew that there were ghettos in Poland already. We Œ we imagined that there Œ I mean, the Jews are Œ had in there, their establishments, professionals, you can go there, buy things with th Œ from the Jews. You can go to the doctor, Jewish doctor, you can go to the lawyer. And then [indecipherable] they live just separately. So, not that bad. But when the ghetto was established, it wasn™t the medieval ghetto, it was Œ everybody was crowded in, in the small place, tak Œ they didn™t work in their professions, they had to work outside, you know, s-simple some Œ digging or something.

segments.question: Did you see people being moved into the ghetto?
segments.answer: No, I didn™t see that. I saw people that were working on Œ on the street with the yellow Œ

segments.question: Star.
segments.answer: Œ with the yellow star. And that also was Œ made a negative impression on the co Œ the Lithuanian people in Panevžys. Tha-That™s Œ that™s too cruel, that™s too cruel. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 175Maybe the Jews did wrong things, maybe th ey deserved some kind of punishment, but this Œ this was too much. And there was a organization, I know, because my mother knows her Œ he Œ she wasn™t pa-part of the organization, but her good friend, this doctor I talked, Dr. Bridges, who talked with the Jewish doctors about, you know, the action of the young Jews during Soviet occupation, his wife, and other, mostly from Catholic organizations, made a Œ a circle to help the Jews in the ghetto. First of all, there was not enough food for them. There was some food, but not enough. So thif Œ that™s first thing what they get for, you know, to Œ to bring food to the ghetto. Ghetto was guarded by Li-Lithuanian au-auxiliaries.

segments.question: So the same sort of auxiliaries as this man who was on a bicycle from Biržai ?
segments.answer: Exactly. Exactly the same. But th-they Œ they didn™t care. They Œ th-they Œ they cou Œ you could bring bread and soda, th-they didn™t want, you know, to Œ to bri Œ they were supposed not to let to [indecipherable] they just didn™t care. And they said, well, we Œ we Œ we buy them, you know, some vodka, you know for this service, but Œ they didn™t ask for that, but it™s Œ so Œ but th-there were quite many Jews, and I don™t know, I Œ I Œ I just dou bt very much that everybody got enough food f Œ by this smuggling, but Œ but some, you know, ap parently held, because it was a rather Œ a rather ma Œ many la Œ wo men were involved in that, so I suppose there was Œ it was Œ it was senseless. I m ean, wa Œ it was something which was a-ab Œ effective to some Œ some degree. And th en, you know, came th at Œ that day of Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 176execution. And the rumor went around that tomorrow the Jews will be killed. First of all, I heard about that from thos Œ these auxiliaries. Some of th-those auxiliaries came to my friends and said, we are not go ing to kill anybody. We are not killers, we are not going to kill anybody. If they force me for such Œ into some executions, we are going to Œ to flee from the service. And they asked my friends, you know, whether we could arrange for them to hide until they could go out of the city toward their villages, and hide there, but right now where Œ when they ha Œ when they escape from this. So apparently Œ by the way, h-here the Bishop of Panevžys comes in. He also heard those rumors and in one Sunday Œ I wasn™t in Œ in the ch Œ in the church, it™s Œ I regret at the time, not a dire ct witness, but the whole city was talking about that, that the bishop s Œ talked about thou sho Œ sh all not kill, and he really condemned those who™d kill innocent people, and excommunicated them in advance. Those who kill innocent people, or you have killed innocent people he excommunicated and Œ and condemned them, not by name, because some of them that just didn™t do that yet. But, as a Œ as a category of people, of Œ of killers. And Œ

segments.question: And he was talking about the massacre of the Jews, the ongoing massacre of the Jews?
segments.answer: Yes, and other innocent people, but Œ

segments.question: Okay. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 177
segments.answer: Œ but he was talking about the Jews. No Œ nobody had any doubt, including the Germans, because the Germans reacted. They arrested the bishop, put in Œ in Œ in the house arrest, and said that he is removed from his Œ from his duties, and he has to leave Panevžys altogether. Okay, so he left Panevžys altogether. He had the villa in Berciunai, a few kilometers from Panevžys , and Œ a small resort, and he went to his vil Œ to this villa. But he didn't resign from a bishop™s duties, he Œ from the villa he just did his old work as a bishop. A nd Lithuanian administration covered it up, you know. So he Œ he was there, you know, and I know Œ

segments.question: What was his name?
segments.answer: Casimiras Paltarokas .

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Casimiras Paltarokas . And so Œ

segments.question: So did these Œ did these auxiliaries who came and asked to be hidden until they could return to their villages, did that succeed? Were they able to run away?
segments.answer: No. I asked after this Œ this thing, you know, my friends wer Œ did they? No, they said, they didn™t need to. There was no Œ no need. There were enough, those who went willingly, and those who refused were left alone, but all of them resigned from the service then, because we have Œ they didn™t want to be associated even with this Œ the killers, the people. So th Œ at least in Panevžys there was no Œ no Œ well, Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 178pressure maybe, but not Œ not really something, you know, forcing to participate in Œ in Œ in executions.

segments.question: So, in other words, those Lithuanians who did participate Œ
segments.answer: Did willingly.

segments.question: Œ did it willingly.
segments.answer: Apparently yeah, that™s Œ that™s the conclusion.

segments.question: And when di Œ do you remember what month the executions started, when the Panevžys Jews were liquidated?
segments.answer: I di Œ I don™t remember now. I have on my Œ on my memoirs Œ

segments.question: Was it Œ or was it in the summer, was it in the early fall?
segments.answer: Oh summer, summer. Late summer, I would say. Maybe late August.

segments.question: Mm-hm. So two or three Œ
segments.answer: Yeah, late August, I would say.

segments.question: So we™re saying June, two or Œ
segments.answer: No, maybe September already. Well, but not Œ not Œ not later than that. Late Œ

segments.question: So two or three months af ter the Germans have invaded?
segments.answer: Less, because half a month June, and July Œ yeah, two, two months.

segments.question: Two months? Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 179
segments.answer: About two months, yes. Appare ntly ki Œ i-in other places of Lithuania what I read, you know, there were executions of various kinds much earlier. But Panevžys was a quiet place, and Œ until the Germans took over, and Œ

segments.question: Did you see Œ after those rumors, wasn™t it true that actually the next day that happened, or the few days afterwards it happ ened Œ I mean, in other words, were the rumors fulfilled?
segments.answer: Which way?

segments.question: I mean, there Œ sometimes one can hear that there are rumors and it doesn™t happen that week, it happens the week after.
segments.answer: No, no, it happened that, because it Œ there were Œ they brought Œ they were telling a story, they brought Russian prisoner s of war to dig the ditches for that. And when they gave the dimensions of the ditc hes, the Russians threw Œ threw off their Œ their shovels and they refused. Because they were Soviet, people they knew, that™s Œ that™s for their Œ for execution. And they assumed for them.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: And the Germans finally tell them that that™s for Jews, not for you. They didn™t believe it. They didn™t believe it. They had to take their equipment, whatever, dig the ditches themselves, or hired sa Œ I don™ t know, but the Russians wouldn™t do that.

segments.question: Interesting.
segments.answer: They were Soviet people, they know what it means to dig a ditch. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 180

segments.question: Yeah, you know Œ
segments.answer: They Œ yeah, well it™s Œ it™s na Œ it™s Œ it™s Œ it™s terrible, it™s terrible. The day when the executions started was somehow very strange, you know. Nobody was talking, people just didn™t talk. People Œ people stopped talking, you know, it was kind of Œ myself, I went, you know, to s Œ visit my friend, who lived near the Œ the street where the road was leading toward Pajuoste where the executions were taking place. And the trucks full of Œ of Jews, I suppose, full of people were just going that direction.

segments.question: Did you see this?
segments.answer: Yes. And to his Œ with my class friend, we just looked, and didn™t say anything. Didn™t say anything because what Œ wh at can you say? What can you say?

segments.question: So it™s like the whole city knows.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: The whole city knows.
segments.answer: Oh yeah, the whole city knew, definitely. And the reaction was horrified, horrified. I don™t know what Œ whether all of them, of course, maybe o-ob Œ obviously, there should have been people who approved. Af-After all, there were people who participated. But generally, you know, when you go to the city and see the people, you Œ you can see that ever ybody™s kind of like paralyzed from horror, what™s going on. You ga Œ the Œ the Œ any revenge, anything about the Jews was Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 181forgotten by that time, long ago. When the Jews were brought into the ghetto, you know, the Lithuanians, th-that Œ that was the end. The Lithuanians didn™t Œ didn™t approve of that; a ghetto as it was established there, didn™t approve of that, and so Œ but yeah, that™s Œ that is a terrible, a terrible thing. Yeah, we Œ we went then, after the execution, oh several, several weeks after the execution, and we went to a farm where one of our friends had the girlfriend iin that farm. The farm was nearest farm to the execution place. And we wanted to find out. We Œ we knew, I mean, it Œ it was a horrible thing happened of a gur Œ trem endous significance. Wanted to find out wa-wa Œ wh-what Œ what it was. And they said well, the girl couldn™t tell us anything because when the executioner cames, the fa Œ th-the Œ the parents, they say, hid her. Told her to go upstairs, yo u know, and the Œ and to hi de, and because those Œ the killers were going around the co Œ the house drinking water, vodka, everything. But we didn™t really, in such a detail as this from Biržai told, there was nothing Œ nothing Œ nothing. The same thing, the same Germans and Lithuanians. German officer also killing, you know, babies. Apparently still there™s some resistance of the executioners to kill babies, so the officer had to take them up on himself. I™m just Œ I suppose, that Œ that™s my deduction. The story was told that, you know, one Lithuanian officer was married to a j Œ Jewish girl, and when the Jews were brought to the ghetto, he went together with her. Lived together with her, and when they Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 182brought to the execution, he went together with her. And he was told, you know, to go out Œ go away, you know. He refused, he went with his wife and was killed there.

segments.question: So you got as close as to the farm next to the execution site?
segments.answer: Right, yeah, wa Œ the group of us.

segments.question: The group of us. But you di dn™t go to the execution site?
segments.answer: Nah, no.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: No. Then they said, you know, at the end of the ex-execution it looked like they became insane. They were drinking vodka, complaining that th-they Œ they cannot get drunk, you know, no matter how much vo dka they drink. And at the end, you know, it was starting g-getting at dusk, you know. And some of them started going Œ the Œ the Jews had to disrobe, they will start going through their Œ within they had hidden some Œ some valuables there, some gold or whatever, some started going through those Œ their Œ their Œ their clothes. And one of them, of the executioners, one of them said that you™re not supposed to that, you know, that™s Œ that™s supposed to leave, you know, for the Œ for the Œ for the Œ the Germans, you know, to take care of it. So what they did, they just shot him and threw hi m together with the Jews in the Œ in the Œ in the Œ in th Œ in the ditch. Now, this is true Œ true story, because about year, or Œ or couple of years ago, my friend came to me and said, you know Œ wanted to check with me his translation of a request of a mother of those Œ that who Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 183was killed there. He was asked Œ she was Œ wanted to translate into German, was asking the German authority to let dig up th e grave, find the remains of her son and remove it and bring it to Œ to its Œ a regular cemetery. So, I saw that Œ that letter, which my friend has translated, we looked at the translation. So I Œ I doubt very much a German would have approved that , I don™t know what happened with that story, but apparently that story is right.

segments.question: So that means the one who was there, who was sayi ng you can™t go through the clothes Œ
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Œ this was his mother.
segments.answer: That™s right.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: That™s right.

segments.question: How many Jews were there in Panevžys ? Do you know, approximately? Are we talking 10,000, are we talking Œ
segments.answer: No, about s-s 7,000 - 8,000, some thing less than 10,000 I would say.

segments.question: And in Biržai , did you have an idea?
segments.answer: Less. Considerably less, but I know, because the city is much smaller.

segments.question: Smaller.
segments.answer: But I Œ I Œ I don™t know, I don™t know. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 184

segments.question: After this, did you hear of other su ch massacres throughout the countryside?
segments.answer: Yeah, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah? What did you hear after the Panevžys massacre? How did Œ how did the next several days play out? When did people start talking again?
segments.answer: Pretty soon, I suppose, but they were still ob-obsessed by that, and were Œ really came back to that theme. I was working at that time. I took a wa Œ a Œ a jo Œ a job in the municipality of Panevžys . We see Germans introduce the food Œ food cards.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: We were supposed to get that much food, you know, for Œ and the Œ this Œ everybody had to get those cards. Now, it™s tremendous operatio n, you know, every people have to get those cards in Panevžys . Tremendous lines and Œ and lots of time. So they hired people, I was one of them, and many of my friends, to bring those to the people. We got those food ca rds, we had lists of people who live and how many, and we were bri nging those cards to the peop le themselves, so they wouldn™t waste time getting those cards. So it was very interesting because I knew pa Œ pa Œ got to know Panevžys as never before. You know, all kinds of people from all professions, all Œ all social levels, you know, all nationalities, except the Jews. Except the Jews. Yeah. And so I brought those cards. Most of the people, you know, just signed for it, a-and I go to the next house and so on. But some of the people were talkative. And Œ and some Œ and all Œ not always, but many of the Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 185people were bringing up this Œ the execution of the Jews, and all negative. I suppose that those who were for it, wouldn™t start the discussion at all. I just met one who Œ who was that, you know.

segments.question: In the bringing of these cards around you mean, or in general you just met one person?
segments.answer: He Œ he Œ he Œ he Œ let me see, did I bring a Œ a cards? Exactly thinking, I think I was bringing the cards, but he was outside, or he was visiting that fa-family, and I didn™t give him the cards, just the regular Œ the residents. And I don™t know, he was officer in Lithuanian army or Œ or what, I don™t remember his Œ his profession, but he said that his Œ he was one of those, when the deportations started who Œ who ran away to hide because he thought th-they are coming for him. And his family was deported. He Œ hi-his wife and two daught ers. And he was convinced that the Jews were in that group, and he said he is going to Œ to participate in killing of the Jews. But I doubt very much, because he was telling when the Jews in Panevžys were already killed, so he had to go to Vilnius or Kaunas, you know, where the executioners were still working. I doubt very much whether he did that, but I don™t know, I don™t know.

segments.question: But his sentiment was there. In other words, he had that Œ
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Œ he had that sentiment. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 186
segments.answer: Right. But that was the only one, and I sup-suppose there were more than that, but I Œ but I Œ I Œ I would imagine that they wouldn™t start that type of conversation.

segments.question: And yet, with the people that Œ who you did have start such conversations, they were still in some shock?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, yes. And th-that™s why they brought up the subject , they just Œ just couldn™t Œ couldn™t hold, they just wa nted to Œ to Œ to speak about it.

segments.question: So all this happened in the first several months after the German invasion?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: And after the German occupation, and we have another three years, or another two and a half years of Œ of German occupation, Nazi occupation of Lithuania . Anything in those next couple of years occu r that was also related to the Holocaust, to the Jewish community, that you came across in your lif e at that time, or was it pretty much over by the fall of 1941?
segments.answer: In Panevžys was over, because no Jews were le ft, unless somebody hid some of the Jews, which happened, as we found out later. At that time nobody w-was bragging about it. So Œ but I went to Vilnius, to study in Vilnius and there were ghetto.

segments.question: Oh yeah, there was a ghetto there.
segments.answer: Ghetto there, really two of them at the beginning. And yeah, but it was so isolated, and was at Œ the wall, they were really under the wall there, s-so they were Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 187so isolated that we didn™t know what™s going on in there. We knew that it Œ we saw some of the Jews being driven to some ki nd of work. We knew they were, some of them, working in the factories, one factory came up in flames because it seems [indecipherable] there sabotage, because they were working for the German army, for the Œ getting the cur Œ th-the furs, you know, for the winter.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Yeah, so Kailis factory. So, but we d Œ we kne w that executions were going on in Paneriai. From time to time they were taking out there and Œ and being killed. We knew that some of the Jews escaped. Es caped Œ not only those which were hidden, but escaped into the forests in vil Œ in Vilnius area and in Kaunas area, I don™t know in other ci-cities. And there joined the Soviet guerillas, Soviet partisans, which the movement, at that time, you know, th-the Œ the Soviet planes were parachuting some of leaders and weapons. And th-there was th at movement of the Soviet partisans, esescaped prisoners of war, Russian prisoners of war escaped. Some of the Lithuanian communists wer Œ survived, and the Jews who escaped from the ghettos. Now, at that time there was Lithuanian resistance movement against the Germans, there was underground press going out, lett ers, and even at that time I noticed one thing. That our press, underground press was reporting what the ger Œ Germans were doing with the Jews. If they killed, you know, thousand or s Œ or Œ or Œ or Œ or so Jews in Kaunas, there was a Œ a Œ a Œ a notice, a report. There were reports about Jewish Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 188guerillas, the Soviet guerillas, but there was no judgment. And even speaking with the people, they didn™t, most of the pe Œ they didn™t speak about those things, but if there was Œ they spoke about the Jewish guerillas, I Œ I didn™t meet anybody who would condemn them. At that time it was clear that they were fighting, that was the only chance to fight for their life. So, ba Œ what Œ what Œ nobody see how Œ how you can condemn them. They were on the other side, they were enemies. Our Lithuanian s-security forces, auxiliaries were fighting against go Œ Soviet guerillas, also against the Jewish Soviet guerillas, but not because they™re Jew, because they were fighting against the Soviets. Well, that was, the war was going on, Lithua nians were fighting Polish guerillas also. But there were no Œ there was not Œ not that, as a div Œ during the first occupation, where there was that resentment. There was no resentment. They were on the other side, they we re like Œ like enemy, which you do not condemn, you know, he Œ I fight for one cause, he is fighting for another.

segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.answer: No, but my Œ one of my friends, who studied together with us in my class, he was working in Lithuanian security under the Germans, and Œ and a-as an officer. He was studying and working in the city already. But his job was in particular, against the Polish underground. He was well Œ and he was killed by the Polish underground when he was trying to arrest so mebody or something like that.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: So I knew him very well.

segments.question: Mm-hm. And did he have anything to say about the workings there, or was he pretty quiet about it?
segments.answer: He was kind of quiet, yeah, generally he was a quiet man. But no-nothing Œ but as far as I know he had nothing to do with the Jews, but I can™t be sure. I can™t be sure, but really against the Poles, and still continued that hostility. Doesn™t matter, you know, because the German occupation, but Lithuanians were still fighting the Jew Œ the Jew Œ the Polish, and the Polish Lithuanian, fighting Lithuanians.

segments.question: Yeah, the Œ
segments.answer: E-E-Even at that time. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 190

segments.question: If there Œ is there anything else that you would like to add to events that touched Œ that again, you heard of, or were inv Œ or were involved in, in a sense of Œ of being in a certain place when something happens, about the Jews during the German occupation?
segments.answer: About the Jews during the German occupation?

segments.question: Yeah. Since you were in Panevžys and you were in Vilnius Œ
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Œ is there any other memory, any other event or instance in those two and a half, three years?
segments.answer: No, not really, except that, you know, in Vilnius I-I was a student, and between the students and Œ and some wa Œ in the higher class, were definitely condemn Œ with old Œ the opinion was condemning thos e who had participated in executions, and even at that time were participating, because more or less, killing of the Jews in Paneriai Œ Austai(ph) Paneriai took place all the time, sometimes less, sometimes more and the killers were working all the time. Of course, killers were killing not only the Jews, they were killing also the Poles, and well, Lithuanians, Germans killed themselves. But th-they killed them also.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah, the Lahavichos (ph) Œ it was territorial defense organization, which General Lahavichos (ph) organized with the agreemen t with Germans, but later, you Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 191know, fell out. Germans arrested him and disa rmed that defense force and killed, you know, hundreds of Œ of his soldiers. And then the, you know, Lithuanians from the east Prussia , not from Klaipdos, but even farther, Tilž and all that, they f Œ they were, you know, fled from Nazis to Lithuania in Vilnius, they arrested and executed them in Austai(ph) Paneriai also.

segments.question: And the reason was because of activities, or because of Œ
segments.answer: Oh, activities, they were pu-publishing in Lithuanian newspaper, Lithuanian books. Well, of course, that was all over, because they had to flee from the Nazis and they came to Lithuania . And Œ but the tils Œ Tilžs Œ Tilžs Œ Tilszin(ph) Gestapo still had, you know, get in Œ in th Œ in their Œ in Œ in their plans, and as far Œ as soon as Germans occupied Lithuania into Vilnius and they came from Tilž, they just took them out and executed the whole two families there. So Œ

segments.question: How Œ I s Œ I have a sense that we™re go n Œ coming close to the end of our story.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: How did things end with you in Lithuania ? What happened with your family? What happened in 1944 as the war was turning? Bring us up to date as how you came to live in the United States.
segments.answer: Well, I Œ I don™t know whether I should go through Œ through small detail, but after university was closed Œ the Germans closed the university. Well, first of all, the Germans, after Stalingrad, which was in Œ Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 192

Œ 1943, which was another turning point, I was very much aware, and most of the people were aware that this a turning point. After Stalingrad we thought maybe, you know, there might be somebody if Œ if the Germans throw the Hitler away, or something may Œ some Œ but most likely Germans have lost the war. So, Germans also realized that they are in bad shape now. So they d ecided oh, Lithuanians wanted to fight against the Soviets, okay, so let™s call Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians, they established Waffen SS legions for those countries and drafted the young men into those Waffen SS legion. Estonian [indecipherable] legion, and Latvian, two divisions. Estonian, one division, Latvian, two divisions. And Lithuanian, Lithuanians just boycotted. Nobody rea lly, excepts few invalids reported to the induction center. Well, they became so angry, they closed the universities, because they realized that the students were behind it, and they arrested the Œ you know, s Œ I don™t know, about 50, maybe less people very known in Lithuania . P-Priests, professors, even their administrators who worked on that dam, high administrators and brought them to the concentration camp in Stutthof , near Danzig. And all the other oppressions, you know, your Œ even Œ even Œ even farmers and so al-al-also. So, once that started Œ well, I d Œ I don™t want to go into lo Œ long details, but I Œ I wa Œ I became sick with a pneumonia and was in the hospital and I was discharged for pneumonia. And the Germans took a list of discharged people and drafted us. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 193And I saw that™s Œ it™s really a sad situation. So I thought that the only thing I have, if I don™t want, you know, that my family will suffer [indecipherable] for that, I Œ I would rather collec Œ select, you know, where do I am going under the Germans. And I selected so-called Reichsarbeitsdienst. A Reichs labor service, which all the Germans had to Œ to go through before going into the m ilitary service, but also the girls had to go through that. So I w Œ I volunteered for that, not wanting to go anywhere else. My resistance leader approved of that.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: He himself was part German, and apparently thought that that™s Œ that™s advantageous to Œ to Œ to Œ to be on that side [indecipherable]

segments.question: So you were an anti-German resistance Œ
segments.answer: I was.

segments.question: Œ as an anti-Nazi resistance [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Right, right, yes. So my leader acce Œ a-approved of that, and I went into the arbeitsdienst. I served for, not the full term. I don™t know why, they let us go earlier. And we came to Lithuania. We knew that, you know, the German Œ

segments.question: Were you Œ excuse me, I™m sorry to interrupt. You weren™t in Lithuania at that point?
segments.answer: No, we went to Germany .

segments.question: I see. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 194
segments.answer: We Œ we work in Peenemünde, we were in several places, but I [indecipherable] in Peenemünde where the German rockets were being built, you know [indecipherable] and Œ and the other. And Mr. Brown was there, you know, I Œ we saw him.

segments.question: You did? You saw him?
segments.answer: Y-Yeah, well, just fleeing, you know, he was walking through there. So, was Œ was Œ German were very correct about that. Apparently they wanted to create some friendly people for them, you know. Was Œ wa s no-not bad at all. And the Germans wo Œ took Œ but we were working together with the Germans, mixed together with the Germans, and they were young boys, bu t friendly. So, was not a bad experience. Wa Œ one Œ bu-but then we were released from that service earlier, before our term was over, because there was supposed to be Lithuanian army, you know, armed forces be Œ being established, and the general said that he needs some experienced soldiers who could be un Œ you know, non-commissioned off Œ o fficers, something like that.

segments.question: Which general, what was his name?
segments.answer: Lahavichos (ph).

segments.question: Lahavichos (ph) okay, him, okay, mm-hm.
segments.answer: Yeah, and Œ an-and so I Œ I went back , you know, was discharged and s Œ joined Lahavichos(ph) army. But that was a short thing, you know, couple months until Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 195Germans, you know, came in conflict with Lahavichos (ph) for many aspects. They di Œ didn™t hold with their agreements. Lahavichos (ph) was a very strong, a very s-stubborn and proud man. We loved him, all the soldiers loved him, he was a real leader. So the Germans arrested him, his staff, as I said, and disbanded this Œ this unit and executed some of them. We were let go earlier, so I lived in my aunt™s house in Œ in the village. And then the Russians approached Lithuania, pretty soon they took Vilnius, was a-approaching Kaunas and I decided, you know, that I Œ I™m not going to wait for them. Some who mo Œ my friends ask me to, you know, join them as guerrilla fighters against the Soviets. I didn™t believe in that, I thought maybe two, three months, not more, you know. I didn™t believe that the west will fight for Lithuania . I decided I go west, and try, you know, to Œ to meet it, the western English, or Americans in Germany, because this was obvious Germany lost the war, that was clear.

data: Did your parents go with you?

No. My mother wanted to go with me, well there was confusion, a lot of confusion. And my pa Œ father wa nted, you know, he was too late. Panev žys was taking without any Œ any ba-battle. Germans just demolished electrical plant and retreated without any ac Œ without any resistance. So my father stayed in Lithuania. My mother eventually went to Germany also, but separately form Œ from myself. I Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 196went to Germany , also, we met at the end of war. I met my mother in Munich, and well, I must tell y Œ if I tell the full story, so I went to the east Prussia .

We were sent to work together with the farmers, to Œ to help the farmers. Apparently, also, before the evacuation, it was clear that the Russians will go in Œ inside. So we were working at the farm, and then suddenly was told everybody has to go to dig ditches against the tanks, to make obstacles to the Soviet tanks coming in. And a lot of Lithuanians, Poles, everything, you know, were brought together, and who were just digging those antitank ditches. Which didn™t help any, apparently, later. We were in Œ in the Œ in the rather famous Œ we later fa Œ became famous in the Œ or infamous really. A village nomar -- Nemmersdorf Œ

segments.question: Oh yeah.
segments.answer: Well, yeah, what Œ Soviets e-e-executed a lot of Germans. All of them, really, who were left there, so Œ who were digging those Œ those anti-tank ditches. Now, one afternoon, you know, after Œ after lunch, we were Œ a break, you know, were eating our lunch and suddenly we noticed that SS troopers have surrounded us all around. And they took out their automatic weapons and one of th em came forward. And in very good Lithuanian language, very good, with no accent, nothing, said that we Lithuanians are all communists, we should be shot right away. We didn™t fight to defend our own country, and we deserve to die row Œ right here and now. But, the Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 197fuehrer is so great in Œ in his Œ you know, that he decided to let us Œ to Œ I mean, to w-wer Œ to fight f Œ for the Germany in this way, you know, of our Œ our shame, that we didn™t defend our country, that we are basically communists at heart, who let us, you know, wer Œ you know Œ well, anyway, to Œ to Œ to Œ to Œ to Œ to parole us from this.

segments.question: Expiate Œ expiate your sin Œ
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Œ in other words.
segments.answer: Expiate my sin. So, and this Œ so. we will be drafted now in the German army as auxiliaries in the Luftwaffe. And wh-who doesn™t, you know, doesn™t appreciate fuehrer™s great move, you know, well, we will know about that, how to handle it. Okay, so Œ so we became German soldiers. Soldiers, no, auxiliaries. No rank, nothing like that. They [indecipherable] gave us uniforms, but without any rank indications, any insignia, and we were aus Œ auxiliaries. We were supposed to do work, we were digging trenches against the sw Œ Swedes in Stralsund in Germany. Stralsund because the Germans at that time thought that Sweden™s will Œ going to join the allies and attack them in the north. So we were digging those trenches after that, you know, the Swedes didn™t attack, so they brought us as ot her tasks. But they were manual tasks, and electrical work, y ou know, something like that. I don™t know whether to tell the story, I Œ I Œ I Œ because Œ are we running out of time? Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 198

segments.question: Yeah, we™ve only got about a minute left on this tape, actually. Okay.
segments.answer: Yeah, well Œ well, anyways, well after the war, I met my Œ my mother. I didn™t go into the prisoner of war, I just deserted from the Germans. I didn™t feel that I owe them anything. And we lived in Germany, I studied in the University of Tübingen, studied law again. And then, you know, my uncle, my mother™s brother brought us to the United States, so Œ

segments.question: And your profession after the war, can you tell us?
segments.answer: After the war, I had various jobs, the bo Œ the first Œ the first job I had was a manual job, polishing Œ buffing the metal.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Brushing Œ buffing the lips tick casings. So th-that was work. It was di-dirty work. Then I worked in textile, and after I st-studied here and completed my studies in University of Connecticut, I Œ and then in New York University Business School, then I worked for the government. I worked in the postal service as an economist, making analyses of new equipment, of ne w buildings, economic analyses in that field, and worked until I retired. And after that, a short time, I worked in Lithuanian mission at the United Nations, when Lithuania became independent. They didn™t have any diplomats, and Mr. Simutas(ph), who was appointed ambassador at the United Nations, asked me to join his staff. Interview with Algimantas Gureckas October 14, 2010 199
